nytimes_articles.headline: Clinton's Dilemma On Court Candidate
nytimes_articles.abstract: After disclosures that Judge Stephen Breyer did not pay Social Security taxes for a housekeeper, Senate backers have started a drive to save his Supreme Court candidacy. But the situation raises difficulties for President Clinton, who dropped two female candidates in similar cases: if he nominates the judge, he risks being accused of a double standard.    Article, page A11.

nytimes_articles.headline: Nevada Town Booms With Proceeds From Gambling Mormons
nytimes_articles.abstract: A giant neon cowboy stands with his toes against the state line here, looming over a landscape of salt flats and alkaline-stunted sage. Wendover Will, he is called. The biggest, friendliest cowpoke in the West.   For three decades he has stood at the Nevada-Utah border, his upraised hand beckoning toward Salt Lake City, 117 miles east of here on Interstate 80, his smile promising a little action in the five casinos at his back.

nytimes_articles.headline: Rebecca Baxt, J. B. Shammash
nytimes_articles.abstract: Rebecca Doria Baxt, a daughter of Dr. Saida and Dr. Sherwood Baxt of Saddle River, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Jonathan Baruch Shammash, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Jacob B. Shammash of Longmeadow, Mass. Rabbi Andre Ungar performed the ceremony at Temple Emanuel in Woodcliff Lake, N.J.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Mysterious and Majestic Challenge for U.S. Open
nytimes_articles.abstract: It might be the most elegant name in golf.   Baltusrol.   The word literally rolls off the tongue, at once distinctive, rhythmic, concise and mysterious. Merely from its sound, it has to be one of the great places in the game.

nytimes_articles.headline: Chow, Anglin Take Singles; Underdog Loses Bite in Final
nytimes_articles.abstract: Everybody loves the underdog. Especially when he laughs at himself on the court, dives for every close ball and wears a forest-green hat backward, though the whole point of a cap is to provide shade from the sun.   Seeded 14th, Erik Sicard was an underdog yesterday in the Mayor's Cup All-Scholastic tennis championships at the U.S.T.A. National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows, Queens, as his enthusiasm and style propelled him into the final. But Sicard, a 15-year-old sophomore at the Dwight School in Manhattan, ran out of what got him to the final round and lost to 18-year-old Peter Chow of Francis Lewis High School in Queens, 6-1, 6-1.

nytimes_articles.headline: Time to Make Sense on Rent Control
nytimes_articles.abstract: New York City's rent regulations expire tomorrow, as they do every two years. And legislators are again at loggerheads over rent controls that masquerade as boons to the city's poor and middle class, but actually hurt them by inflating the cost of housing and robbing the city of badly needed tax revenues.   There's not much good about rent controls, despite their undeserved popularity among tenants. They reduce property tax revenues, discourage construction of new rental apartments and speed the deterioration of older housing. Controls are making a sick real estate market sicker. Costs are up, the economy is down and owners cannot recoup their losses through rents.

nytimes_articles.headline: Is Clinton Moving to Left, Right or Center?; First at the Wall
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Your report of President Clinton's appearance at the ceremony before the Vietnam Veterans Memorial (front page, June 1) contains the remarkable observation that he was the first President to attend Memorial Day services there in the 12 years since the wall's construction.

nytimes_articles.headline: Agassi Is Firing His Forehand Again
nytimes_articles.abstract: He may be wearing even more white than is necessary, in the form of a bandage to soothe his ailing right wrist, but Andre Agassi, the undisputed peacock of the male tennis circuit and the unlikely defending champion of Wimbledon, has vowed to return to the scene of his greatest career triumph and attempt to defend his first and only Grand Slam crown.   A week from today, Agassi, who transcended his baseline heritage last year to defeat Goran Ivanisevic in a stirring five-set Wimbledon final, expects to commence his title defense despite being unable, as recently as last Monday, to hit his favorite stroke, the forehand blast, because of pain in his right wrist.

nytimes_articles.headline: Is Clinton Moving to Left, Right or Center?; A Rigorous Standard
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Anna Quindlen doesn't seem to understand in "A Fragile Truce" (column, June 2) the difference between opposition to the Vietnam War, which is not dishonorable, and evading wartime service to one's country through influence and manipulation of the system, which is dishonorable. It is the second that I and many other veterans find abhorrent.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Immigrant Dream Realized in One Evening
nytimes_articles.abstract: They're under age, overdressed and spending incredible amounts of money. Ah, romance. It's prom night, and some of the most glamorous couples out on the town are 17 years old.    Nobody has to tell them about real life; they live here, remember? But for one night, they could dress up and pretend it was 1953. She wore something supremely sophisticated, and he showed up with flowers for his best girl.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Noble Loser
nytimes_articles.abstract: If it's true that the great peaks in human civilization tend to produce the greatest artists, then it follows that the great valleys will produce some real losers. Well, the New York Mets, now plumbing baseball depths unseen since the amazin' summer of 1962, have produced a player who's approaching an 82-year-old record for futility. Anthony Young, a young pitcher of some promise, lost his 21st game in a row yesterday, when he was beaten by the Phillies, 5 to 3. He is closing steadily on the major league mark of 23, set in 1910-11 by Cliff Curtis of the old (and legendarily inept) Boston Braves.   Mr. Young endures all this with remarkable dignity, acknowledging the pain of his predicament but never giving in to it by whining. That attitude -- and the occasional strong performance -- is what keeps him in the rotation, and in the hunt for the record. Paradoxically, you have to be pretty good to lose that many in a row -- if you're completely overmatched, you'll be back in the bush leagues in a second.

nytimes_articles.headline: Health Care Emerges as Issue at Bishops' Meeting
nytimes_articles.abstract: The overhaul of the nation's health-care system and its potential links with abortion will vie for attention with theological intricacies and sexual scandals when the nation's Roman Catholic bishops meet this week in New Orleans.    Catholic-affiliated hospitals are an important component of the American medical system, and the bishops are torn between their longstanding pleas for changes in the health-care system and their opposition to including payment for abortions in a national health insurance plan.

nytimes_articles.headline: No Community Without Democracy
nytimes_articles.abstract: With Denmark's Maastricht doubts resolved and British ratification of the treaty virtually assured, Euro-enthusiasts are again urging vigorous moves toward political and monetary union. They are calling on European Community nations to relaunch the drive

nytimes_articles.abstract: VATICAN CITY - [From our New York edition:] Pope Pius XII appealed yesterday [June 13] for discipline and faith among the world's workmen and at the same time denounced "propaganda of anti-religious inspiration...that the Pope supports the war and su

nytimes_articles.headline: Marilyn Greenberg and Mark Morril
nytimes_articles.abstract: Marilyn S. Greenberg, a painter in New York, was married yesterday to Mark Charles Morril, the general counsel of Paramount Publishing in New York. Cantor Bruce Ruben officiated at the Stanhope hotel in Manhattan.   Ms. Greenberg, who is keeping her name, graduated from Temple University and received master's degrees in art and in fine art from Rutgers University. She is the daughter of George and Frances Greenberg of Palm Beach, Fla. Her father, now retired, was the chairman and chief executive of Loehmann's, the women's clothing store chain, in the Bronx. The bride's previous marriage ended in divorce, as did the bridegroom's.

nytimes_articles.abstract: Baseball  American League   BOSTON RED SOX -- Placed Scott Fletcher, infielder, on the 15-day disabled list, retroactive to June 10. Activated Jeff Richardson, infielder, from the 15-day disabled list.   MILWAUKEE BREWERS -- Assigned Wayne Housie, outfielder, to New Orleans of the American Association.

nytimes_articles.headline: Adam Owett and Shana Fox-Martin
nytimes_articles.abstract: Shana Fox-Martin, the daughter of Nancy Fox-Martin of New York and Amsterdam, and the late Milton Fox-Martin, was married yesterday to Adam Thomas Owett, the son of Bernard and Trudy Owett of New York. Rabbi Dennis Math performed the ceremony at the Hudson River Club in New York.   Mrs. Owett, 24, is a student at Baruch College in New York. Her father was a marketing consultant in Amsterdam for European hotels. Her mother, now retired, was a textile designer in Amsterdam.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. Expresses Regret At Shooting of Somalis
nytimes_articles.abstract: American officials expressed regret today over the shooting deaths of Somali women and children in Mogadishu, but defended the actions of the United Nations troops there as understandable.   Witnesses and hospital workers said Pakistani troops had fired into crowds of unarmed women and children, killing about 20 and wounding 50. But a Pakistani Foreign Ministry spokesman in Islamabad said the troops returned fire after being attacked by an armed Somali group, and strongly denied that Pakistani forces had fired on a defenseless crowd.

nytimes_articles.headline: Carin L. Levine, Roger Ehrenberg
nytimes_articles.abstract: Carin Lynn Levine, a doctoral candidate in clinical psychology at St. John's University, was married yesterday to Roger Ehrenberg, an investment banker with Citibank in New York. Rabbi Marjorie Slome officiated at the Coveleigh Club in Rye, N.Y.   The bride and her husband, both 27, graduated with honors from the University of Michigan. She is the daughter of Marcia Graydon of South Orange, N.J., and Charles Levine of Brooklyn. Her mother is a lawyer in South Orange. Her father is a general manager at Sikanib Corporation, a construction company in New York, and a real estate developer

nytimes_articles.headline: Tax's Demise Illustrates First Rule Of Lobbying: Work, Work, Work
nytimes_articles.abstract: Jim Mc Avoy remembers well when he and a cadre of the capital's top lobbyists held their first meeting to plot the demise of President Clinton's energy tax. It was December 1992, Mr. McAvoy recalls: "I left it, and went straight to our Christmas party."   Not only was the tax plan little more than Washington dinner-party grist; the President wasn't even the President yet. Mr. Clinton would not suggest squeezing money from British thermal units until February. Congress would not vote on a B.T.U. tax until May.

nytimes_articles.headline: Next Wave Festival to Open With Premiere
nytimes_articles.abstract: The American premiere of Steve Reich's first music theater work, "The Cave," the New York premieres of Philip Glass's latest opera, "Orphee," and "Billboards," a Joffrey Ballet production based on the music of Prince, are among the highlights of the 11th Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The festival is to open on Oct. 13, with Mr. Reich's work, and run through Dec. 4, when the Brooklyn Philharmonic and the Mercer Ellington Jazz Band will perform works by Duke Ellington.    Also among the productions scheduled is the long-postponed American premiere of "The Black Rider," a collaboration between the director Robert Wilson, the songwriter Tom Waits and the author William S. Burroughs (Nov. 20 to Dec. 1).

nytimes_articles.headline: Is Clinton Moving to Left, Right or Center?; The View From Europe
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   On my return from a trip to Europe last week, I was bombarded by news of President Clinton's haircuts and his travel office. Big deal, especially after years of watching recent Governments misuse our tax money.

nytimes_articles.headline: Grand Prix of Canada Leaves Andretti Stalled in Pits
nytimes_articles.abstract: The banner in the grandstands opposite Michael Andretti's garage will do as a title for his weekend here at the Grand Prix of Canada. It read: "Go Micheal."   A positive message, but someone got their wires crossed.

nytimes_articles.headline: Court Pens Act as Breeding Ground for TB and Other Illnesses
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   In "How New York City Confronts the Problem of TB in Its Jails" (letter, June 1), the Commissioners of Health and Correction make a persuasive case that the Dinkins administration is acting on the tuberculosis situation in the city's jails. But the city has ignored the serious health problems in another component of its criminal justice system, the pre-arraignment court pens.

nytimes_articles.headline: Judith Friend, Andrew Popik
nytimes_articles.abstract: Dr. Judith Nancy Friend, a daughter of Carol Kenyon of Scotch Plains, N.J., and Karl E. Friend of Emmaus, Pa., was married last evening to Andrew H. Popik, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Selig R. Popik of Spring Valley, N.Y. Rabbi Louis Frishman performed the ceremony at Temple Beth-El in Spring Valley.   Dr. Friend is keeping her name. She is an associate veterinarian at the Westfield (N.J.) Veterinary Group. She graduated cum laude from Cornell University, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. She received her veterinary degree from the New York State College of Veterinary Medicine.

nytimes_articles.headline:
GOLF;
Played Like a Hall of Famer: Sheehan Wins the L.P.G.A.
nytimes_articles.abstract:
For most athletes, gaining entry into a hall of fame is a sign that their greatest glories are behind them. But Patty Sheehan, who gained a spot in the Ladies Professional Golf Association Hall of Fame three months ago, is right in the midst of one of the best seasons of her memorable career.

This afternoon, the 36-year-old veteran from Reno capped four days of steady play with a workmanlike 69 on the tight, hilly Bethesda Country Club course, giving her a four-day total of nine-under-par 275 and victory in the $1 million Mazda L.P.G.A. Championship over a group of dogged but vastly inexperienced pursuers.

nytimes_articles.headline: Books of The Times; From Tulips to Mergers: Speculative Psychology
nytimes_articles.abstract: A Short History of Financial Euphoria  By John Kenneth Galbraith Illustrated. 113 pages. Whittle Books in Association with Viking. $16.   It looks at first as if in "A Short History of Financial Euphoria," John Kenneth Galbraith is offering just what his title suggests, a brief account of famous speculative episodes like the mania over tulips that hit Amsterdam in the early 17th century, the South Sea Bubble of the 19th century and the Wall Street crash of 1929.

nytimes_articles.headline: Gems Reported Taken at Convention Center
nytimes_articles.abstract: About $900,000 in gold, jewelry and precious stones disappeared from a locked storage room at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center on the West Side of Manhattan, two exhibitors told the police yesterday.   Representatives of the exhibitors, Rex Jewelers and Esquire Jewelry, said they put the jewelry and loose gems into a footlocker and a suitcase, taped both shut and locked them in the storage room at 6:30 P.M. Saturday.

FEINBERG, whose client, Judge Stephen G. Breyer, failed to pay taxes for a maid. BOREN, who said he would re-examine his support of Judge Breyer.  [ A11:5. ]

nytimes_articles.headline: DOCTORS ANNOUNCE WAY TO FORESTALL EFFECT OF DIABETES
nytimes_articles.abstract: In what doctors termed the most important discovery for diabetics since insulin, researchers said today that the devastating complications of the disease could be prevented or delayed.    They said this was possible when diabetics closely monitored their blood sugar levels with a special meter throughout the day and injected themselves with insulin four to seven times daily to keep their blood sugar at a near-normal level. In current practice, most patients do not monitor their blood so closely and give themselves one or two doses of insulin a day, which allows their blood sugar to vary greatly.

nytimes_articles.headline: Alison Lazarus, Clifford Gevirtz
nytimes_articles.abstract: Alison Meg Lazarus, the director of sales for the Knopf Publishing Group at Random House Inc. in New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Clifford Mark Gevirtz, an attending anesthesiologist at the Montefiore Medical Center and an assistant professor of anesthesiology at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx. Rabbi Deborah A. Hirsch officiated at Bridgewaters in New York.   Ms. Lazarus, 35, is keeping her name. She graduated from the State University of New York at Binghamton. She is a daughter of Joan G. Lazarus of Ossining, N.Y., and the late Theodore R. Lazarus.

nytimes_articles.headline: Book on Anita Hill Greeted by Hysteria
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Anthony Lewis, in "Sleaze With Footnotes" (column, May 21), accuses critics and columnists who have given my book "The Real Anita Hill" serious and respectful reviews of failing to check my facts.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: WARREN E. BURGER , the former Chief Justice of the United States, will receive the Betsy Ross Freedom Award at Flag Day ceremonies in Philadelphia today.   Mr. Burger will be the principal speaker at the ceremony, which marks the 216th anniversary of the adoption of the Stars and Stripes by the Continental Congress in 1777. The event will be held in front of the Betsy Ross House, where legend has it that the famous flag was sewn.

nytimes_articles.headline: Essay; Too Many Russians
nytimes_articles.abstract: There's a telephone directory in my hotel room.   To people accustomed to freedom, that's expected. But to anyone who worked even for short bursts in the oppressive atmosphere of the Soviet Union, a telephone book is a symbol of freedom. In the old days, unless you were an official or had a K.G.B. contact, you could never get a list of numbers; the Soviets did not want people communicating.

nytimes_articles.headline: Canada's Tories Name Woman Prime Minister
nytimes_articles.abstract: Defense Minister Kim Campbell was elected tonight to head the Progressive Conservative Party and to be the first woman to serve as Canada's Prime Minister.   Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, in the last year of his second five-year term, announced his resignation in February, leading to today's convention.

nytimes_articles.headline: Gianna Zuccotti and Mark Lieb
nytimes_articles.abstract: Dr. Gianna Zuccotti, a daughter of John and Susan Zuccotti of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Mark Lieb, the son of Marvin and Beverly Lieb of Lido Beach, L.I. The Rev. Louis Gigante, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel officiated at the home of the bride's parents in East Hampton, L.I.   Dr. Zuccotti, 26, is keeping her name. She is a resident in internal medicine at New York Hospital. She graduated from Wellesley College and received a medical degree from the Mount Sinai School of Medicine.

nytimes_articles.headline: WHAT THEY'RE READING
nytimes_articles.abstract: Robertson Davies, whose latest novel is "Murther & Walking Spirits," is "rereading" the novels of Angus Wilson. .Davies says he was "moved to do so because of the fine Masterpiece Theatre series of 'Anglo-Saxon Attitudes.'

nytimes_articles.headline: An Artist a Lot More at Home Away From Home
nytimes_articles.abstract: Richard Serra was in his element. Partly, that meant he was in Europe, which he believes has always supported his work more loyally and intelligently than the United States. Unfortunately, it also meant Reykjavik, Iceland, and a rain driven nearly horizontal to the grass-tufted volcanic rock and mixed with pinpricks of hail. "I love this light," he said, squinting up at the implacable, slate-gray sky. "And I love the look of the piece when it's wet."   He had a point. "Afangar" -- the name was taken from an Icelandic epic and means something like "wandering about in a contemplative mood" -- consists of nine pairs of hexagonal stone pillars, natural crystalline formations hacked from a quarry in the middle of Iceland and transported to the site. The pairs outline the small island on which the piece stands, like Viking totems. When the weather is dry, the stones look light gray and are flecked with bird droppings. Wet, they're shiny and black, Nordic cousins of the Jupiterian sentinels in the film "2001."

nytimes_articles.headline: Abroad at Home; The Powell Factor
nytimes_articles.abstract: At a lunch for the honorary degree recipients on Harvard's commencement day Gen. Colin Powell was asked to say a few words to the guests. When he finished, a woman who has been critical of the military said to a friend: "I'm going to start Pacifists for Powell."   In 24 hours here General Powell all but charmed birds from the trees. When he spoke extemporaneously, he was thoughtful, gracious, direct, easy. Then he delivered a formal speech to thousands, including protesters on the issue of gays in the military, and got a standing ovation.

nytimes_articles.headline: "PULSE: Suspended Licenses"
nytimes_articles.abstract: In New York City, convictions for driving on a suspended or revoked license rose by 13.4 percent to j2,702 in 1991, from 2,364 the year before. Another 47,824 drivers were convicted for driving without a license, a decline of 10.3 percent from 1990.    Statewide, 43,555 drivers were convicted of driving on revoked, or suspended licenses in 1991, a decrease of 6.8 percent from the previous year. Most suspensions reflected a failure to respond to a traffic or parking summons. Licenses were revoked most oten for driving while intoxicated (25.4%); driving without insurance (22.5%); accumulating 3 or more moving violations in 18 months (7.9%), or refusing an alcohol test (7.3%). An additional 21.9% were out-of-state drivers convicted of violations in New York.

nytimes_articles.headline: Red, White, Blue and 1 Goal Short
nytimes_articles.abstract: In the most popular sport in the world, the Germans are known for their raging garrison comebacks. No lead is safe, because these people do not know how to quit.   But today the world champions of soccer had to hang on for a 4-3 victory over the United States here in the U.S. Cup tournament, as a crowd of 53,549 spectators at Soldier Field roared for one more late goal.

nytimes_articles.headline: Feinstein, at Stanford, Warns Of Too Hasty Military Trims
nytimes_articles.abstract: Senator Dianne Feinstein delivered the main address yesterday at Stanford University's 102d commencement exercise, held at Stanford Stadium. A member of Stanford's class of '55, Ms. Feinstein, a Democrat from San Francisco, was elected in November as one of California's first two female United States Senators.   "It is time for a rational plan for defense conversion instead of the random closing of bases and the piecemeal cancellation of defense contracts," Ms. Feinstein said. "Otherwise, we risk losing, for both state and nation, the greatest resources of scientific, technical and human capital ever gathered together in human history."

nytimes_articles.headline: Richard A. Licht, Roanne Sragow
nytimes_articles.abstract: Judge Roanne Sragow of the District Court of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts in Cambridge was married yesterday to Richard A. Licht, a former Lieutenant Governor of Rhode Island and a partner in the law firm of Licht & Semonoff in Providence, R.I. Rabbi Samuel Chiel performed the ceremony at the Ritz-Carlton in Boston.   The bride graduated from Tufts University and received a law degree from Boston College. She is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack I. Sragow of Rockville Centre, L.I. Her father is the executive vice president of Tahari Ltd., a manufacturer of women's clothes in New York. Her mother, Kaye Sragow, now retired, was a nurse and a teacher of health and nutrition at the Bret Harte School in Cherry Hill, N.J.

nytimes_articles.headline: T-Shirts Forsaken In Favot Of Top Hats
nytimes_articles.abstract: They're under age, overdressed and spending incredible amounts of money. Ah, romance. It's prom night, and some of the most glamorous couples out on the town are 17 years old.    Nobody has to tell them about real life; they live here, remember? But for one night, they could dress up and pretend it was 1953. She wore something supremely sophisticated, and he showed up with flowers for his best girl.    Maybe Mom and Dad missed their prom because they were too cool for formals and lavender cummerbunds, but not these teen-agers. Prom is hip again, they say.

nytimes_articles.abstract: PARIS - Professor Samuel Pozzi, the celebrated French surgeon, was shot and killed last night [June 13] at his Paris residence by a madman, who immediately after his crime committed suicide. This death deprives us of one of the greatest surgeons of whom F

nytimes_articles.headline: Suzanne Albin, Robert Tucker
nytimes_articles.abstract: Suzanne Rebecca Albin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Albin of Northport, L.I., was married yesterday to Robert Neal Tucker, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Nelson Tucker. Rabbi Shlomo Blickstein officiated at the Roslyn Country Club in Roslyn Heights, L.I.

nytimes_articles.headline: Halissee Skips the Crown And Again Rules on Grass
nytimes_articles.abstract: In the afterglow of the Triple Crown campaign, careers are being shaped these days by 3-year-old horses who did not run in the Kentucky Derby, the Preakness and the Belmont Stakes. And one of them, the colt Halissee, gave a stylish shape to his own career yesterday when he won the Hill Prince Stakes at Belmont Park for his fourth straight victory on the turf.   Halissee, a gray son of the grass star Cozzene and a grandson of the speed horse Fappiano, teamed up with Julie Krone for the second time in four weeks and outran a short field of four rivals. He led nearly all the way but didn't clinch anything until the homestretch. Then he stretched it out and got to the wire 2 1/2 lengths in front of Proud Shot, who had half a length on Logroller for second palce.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Test of Assumptions On Race and on Politics
nytimes_articles.abstract: MATCH the two quotations with their speakers:   1: "It's important that we talk about diversity, but at the same time the parties we're trying to help must contribute to their own well-being."

nytimes_articles.headline: After Three Overtimes, the Suns Say Not Yet!
nytimes_articles.abstract: For the Phoenix Suns, tonight was a test of character. It was a test of endurance. And it was a test of how badly they wanted their season to continue.   The Suns passed on all counts. In a triple-overtime thriller that left both teams drained, Phoenix outlasted the Chicago Bulls, 129-121, in Game 3 of the National Basketball Association finals at Chicago Stadium.

nytimes_articles.headline: Egypt Executes a Terrorist In Drive on Fundamentalists
nytimes_articles.abstract: In a sharpening of the conflict between the Government and the Islamic movement, Egypt announced today the first of what it said would be many executions of militants convicted of terrorism.    The execution was the first of a member of the Islamic movement since five were put to death in 1982 for the killing of President Anwar el-Sadat.

nytimes_articles.headline: Finding Help in New York: Step 1, Smash a Police Car
nytimes_articles.abstract: With a gun jammed against his neck and the threat of death if he did not hand over more cash, a resourceful livery-cab driver came up with a sure-fire way to get help late Saturday night: he crashed his cab into two police cars parked outside a station house in Queens.   "There was no police outside at the time," the driver, Elioth Kersaint, explained yesterday. "Because nobody was there, I had to crash the police cars."

nytimes_articles.headline: State Comptroller Assails Dinkins's Pact on Budget
nytimes_articles.abstract: State Comptroller H. Carl McCall yesterday sharply criticized the $31.2 billion budget agreement reached over the weekend between Mayor David N. Dinkins and leaders of the City Council, saying there were "serious questions about its soundness."   The criticism by Mr. McCall, who has been in the job just six weeks, comes as a rebuke to the Mayor on several levels. Not only is Mr. McCall the state's second highest official and top fiscal monitor, he is also a longtime friend and political ally of Mr. Dinkins. Prior to becoming Comptroller, Mr. McCall was president of the New York City Board of Education, a Dinkins appointee.

nytimes_articles.headline: Brown Takes Old Baggage to a New Port
nytimes_articles.abstract: When Larry Brown was a boy of 7, he lived with his mother and his older brother in a second-floor apartment. This was after the sudden death by heart attack of his father. The apartment was above his grandfather's and his uncles' bakery on Park Avenue in Long Beach, L.I. The bakery was called Hittelman's, for his mother's family name.   Brown remembers sleeping in a room beside one that contained some of the foodstuffs that would later be baked into, among other items, onion rolls and chocolate cake and raspberry rugelach. Sometimes his Russian immigrant grandfather would be too tired after work to walk the mile or so home, and so would sleep in the same bed with Larry.

nytimes_articles.headline: Is Clinton Moving to Left, Right or Center?; Creative Dialogue
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   The reason there is so much apparent confusion associated with the Clinton Administration is that for the first time since Franklin D. Roosevelt a President is engaging the nation in a creative dialogue, which by its nature generates confusion and frustration until it's mastered.

nytimes_articles.headline: Brewers Are Happy to See Sea Gulls, Yankees Leave
nytimes_articles.abstract: By the third inning, the Brewer fans were reduced to cheering for a couple of dogs. With dozens of sea gulls congregating at County Stadium for the third straight night and the Brewers in the midst of absorbing a messy turnaround in the score, the fans wanted entertainment. They wanted to see Gus and Sarge.   While Sarge staged a splendid solo in chasing away the sea gulls, and as Gus watched on standby, the Brewers did not display any such spunk against the resurgent Yankees. After racing to a 3-0 lead over Jimmy Key in the first inning, Milwaukee saw its pitching ravaged by the Yankees, who tied the game in the second, went ahead with four runs in the third and ended the game with a 9-5 victory.

nytimes_articles.headline: Shari R. Waldbaum, Lee D. Feinberg
nytimes_articles.abstract: Shari Renee Waldbaum, a lawyer at the Labor Department in Washington, was married yesterday to Lee Daniel Feinberg, an aerospace engineer at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration in Greenbelt, Md. Rabbi Melvin Sirner performed the ceremony at Beth El Synagogue in New Rochelle, N.Y.   The bride, 27, graduated from the State University at Binghamton, N.Y., and received a law degree from American University. She is the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gerald Waldbaum of New Rochelle.

nytimes_articles.headline: Amid the Rubble, Bonilla Finds His Bat
nytimes_articles.abstract: There aren't many lightning-rod athletes who can point to the exact time and place where the barometer changed dramatically for them.   Bobby Bonilla can.   The time was last Monday night. The place was Shea Stadium. And for the first time in recent memory, the fans did not boo.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bosnian Croats and Muslims Urge Troops to Halt Fighting
nytimes_articles.abstract: In a move that only stirred skepticism among United Nations officials, Bosnia's collective presidency, which contains Croats and Serbs as well as Muslims, issued a cease-fire order tonight to end the fighting between Muslims and Croats in central Bosnia.   International mediators had arranged a rare meeting of the seven-member presidency in the hope of persuading Muslim and Croatian politicians to consider proposals for power-sharing in the few regions of Bosnia and Herzegovina that are not occupied by Serbian forces.

nytimes_articles.headline: INSIDE
nytimes_articles.abstract: Civil War Threat in Cambodia   The leader of Cambodia's royalist party, a son of Prince Norodom Sihanouk, threatened war unless his half brother halts the secession movement he is leading. Page A3. Joining International Radio   Officials say Voice of America and Radio Free Europe-Radio Liberty will be merged, saving $250 million over the next few years. Page A16. Early Astronaut Dies    Deke Slayton, a NASA manager and one of the original seven astronauts profiled in "The Right Stuff," died of brain cancer. He was 69. Page B9. Suns Win in Triple Overtime    Phoenix defeated Chicago, 129-121, in triple overtime to trim the Bulls' lead to 2-1 in the N.B.A. championship series. SportsMonday, page C1.

nytimes_articles.headline: PRO BASKETBALL: Sports of The Times; The Heart and Grit of Sir Charles
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE bald, wounded warrior, one Charles Barkley, his bare skull gleaming in the Chicago Stadium lights last night, his charcoal-dark eyebrows skewed in tension, his sore right, shooting elbow encased in a bulky wrap, led the Phoenix Suns to a most improbable but stupendous triple-overtime victory over the home team, the defending champs, the Michael Jordan Chicago Bulls.   It wasn't all Barkley, to be sure -- there were Kevin Johnson and Dan Majerle and Tom Chambers, among others -- but Barkley's grit pervaded the entire Suns team, as it did in Game 2, though that was in a losing cause.

nytimes_articles.headline: More Misadventures for Anthony Adverse
nytimes_articles.abstract: Anthony Young walked to the pitcher's mound at Shea Stadium early yesterday afternoon, bent down and gently scooped a baseball from the dirt.   So began the sad, slow march to the inevitable.

nytimes_articles.headline: Rafsanjani Re-elected in Iran, But Without a Huge Mandate
nytimes_articles.abstract: Results issued today showed that President Hashemi Rafsanjani won re-election as expected on Friday, but without the overwhelming mandate he had sought to push through free-market reforms and convince the world that support for Iran's Islamic Government has not faltered.   The President won 63 percent of the 16.3 million votes cast in the four-way race. In the last presidential election, in July 1989, he faced one challenger and won 94.5 percent of the vote.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Television; Baedeker of Fun and Games In the Outback Down Under
nytimes_articles.abstract: "Rough Guide," the BBC travel series that enters the PBS lists this week, is plainly aimed at a youngish set of jet setters. The with-it, if not excessively witty, young hosts, the insistent music, the fast takes and jagged editing and the unexpected sites and sights have teeny tourist written all over them. Subtitles offer bits of information, like the fact that Melbourne is the third largest Greek city in the world.   The first of the eight programs bops around Australia, from the Great Barrier Reef to the outback to Melbourne. You can see young folks, many of them from Japan, disporting in the town of Cairns, snorkeling, cliff jumping and admiring aboriginal art. Out in the bush, you can watch a jillaroo (a female sheepherder) doing a job of castration and a pair of kangaroo hunters doing their job. And in Melbourne you can join some people who spend their off hours exploring sewers, and then you can attend the Bachelors and Spinsters Ball, among partyers in formal dress who go in for mud wrestling.

nytimes_articles.headline: Library of Congress Buys Charles Mingus Archive
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Library of Congress has acquired the comprehensive papers of Charles Mingus, the jazz bass player, band leader and composer. The papers include his scores, recordings, photographs, correspondence and original manuscripts.   Jon Newsom, assistant chief of the library's music division, said recently that the acquisition was the most important of its kind in the library's history. He said the papers, which include several hundred compositions, would be difficult to quantify, but he described them as "one very prolific musician's lifework." The library has the papers of many other American composers, including Aaron Copland, Leonard Bernstein, Richard Rodgers, George Gershwin and John Philip Sousa, as well as the recordings of Duke Ellington.

nytimes_articles.headline: Tammy Landa, David A. Fisher
nytimes_articles.abstract: Tammy Landa, the daughter of Harriet Landa of Boca Raton, Fla., and William Landa of North Miami Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Dr. David Alexander Fisher, a son of Drs. Hyman and Rosalie Fisher of Livingston, N.J. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein officiated at the Essex House in New York.   Mrs. Fisher, 30, is a development executive at the UJA-Federation in New York. She graduated from Boston University. Her father is the president of Landa Associates, a real estate company in North Miami Beach.

nytimes_articles.headline: Michele Reis And Todd Melet
nytimes_articles.abstract: Michele Ingrid Reis, a daughter of Barbara and Ralph Reis of Westport, Conn., was married there yesterday to Todd Benjamin Melet, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Melet of Flint, Mich. Rabbi Robert Orkand performed the ceremony at Temple Israel.

nytimes_articles.headline: METRO DIGEST
nytimes_articles.abstract: METRO DIGEST  PEDDLER'S BLANKET, IMMIGRANT'S DREAM   Immigrants selling everything from purses and bracelets to Wayne Newton cassettes have created a makeshift marketplace directly in front of the Immigration and Naturalization Service headquarters at 26 Federal Plaza in lower Manhattan, even though most of them are here illegally. Speaking mother tongues as diverse as Quechua, Wolof and Chinese, they have developed a camaraderie that ignores the fact that many sell the same wares. Together they play cat-and-mouse games with the police. And together they slough off public antagonism with the firm belief that they are earning an honest living. A1.  LAW HOPES FOR LONGER, STRONGER ARMS   Shaken by the stranding of nearly 300 illegal Chinese immigrants aboard a tramp steamer off New York last week, after a surge of similar smuggling attempts along the coasts of Florida and California, Federal officials say they are developing an arsenal of new counter-smuggling tactics: wiretaps, far-reaching conspiracy statutes and the ability to seize money and property obtained through smuggling. Penalties for smuggling immigrants would be stiffened, too, rising to perhaps a maximum of 20 years in prison, up from five years now. Federal officials say they are also urging that intelligence satellites and other sophisticated monitoring devices that have been used in the fight against international drug traffickers be brought to bear against immigrant smugglers. A1. NEW YORK CITY

nytimes_articles.headline: Unlicensed Peddlers, Unfettered Dreams
nytimes_articles.abstract: At 11 A.M. on a recent morning, Louis Ndlovu King of South Africa dragged a duffel bag packed with purses to the sidewalk at the corner of Broadway and Duane Street. Minutes later, Luis and Marcelo Yamberlo, father and son, arrived laden with hand-woven sweaters and bracelets from Ecuador, their native land. Following them, M. Hu, recently smuggled in from China, wheeled a cart neatly stacked with imitation Montblanc pens to the same spot.   Within 30 minutes, the sidewalks in front of the Jacob K. Javits Federal Building were throbbing with the sales pitches of immigrant vendors illegally hawking "Black Is Beautiful" T-shirts, Wayne Newton cassettes, "Pinocchio" videos, batteries, mood rings, sunglasses, flowered panties and butane lighters.

nytimes_articles.headline: Keep Cutting at the Pentagon
nytimes_articles.abstract: President Clinton's hopes to put the nation on a sound fiscal footing depend heavily on disciplining the defense budget now and for years to come. The Pentagon is now showing more willingness to help. But it will need to do more.   As reported Saturday, the Pentagon is scaling down its unrealistic strategy and no longer planning to fight two big wars at once. And it is considering cancellation of some costly new weapons systems. But it needs to cancel more if it is to avoid putting a jumbo mortgage on future revenues.

nytimes_articles.headline: Dance in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: School of American Ballet  Juilliard Theater    The School of American Ballet's 29th annual workshop performances came to a celebratory end last Monday night. The evening started with the presentation of four Mae L. Wien Awards by Peter Martins, the faculty chairman, to Suki Schorer, a faculty member; Miriam Mahdaviani, a choreographer, and Jennie Somogyi and Edward Liang, students who have just been accepted into City Ballet as apprentices. The award is for excellence and promise and is intended for students, teachers and choreographers at the school, an affiliate of the New York City Ballet.    Mr. Liang, seen in a role debut leading the Czardas in George Balanchine's "Cortege Hongrois," epitomized the joyous expertise of these young dancers. He stood out for his resiliency, crispness and endearing passion. The lead cast was completed by Michelle Merrell, his partner, and Ms. Somogyi and Christopher Macdougall.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sussex Force Only Looks Like Police
nytimes_articles.abstract: Lieut. Frank Raeder, all 6 feet 9 inches of him, and three fellow private security guards began patrolling the streets of this tiny community in the hills of northwestern New Jersey this month. They drive bright white cars with a blue stripe and a rooftop rack of red lights. They wear crisp uniforms of navy and Columbia blue, with a polished leather belt bearing handcuffs, a portable radio, and a 9-millimeter handgun.   They look, for all the world, like police officers, maybe even looking a bit more natty than the four officers town officials dismissed early last year after a drug scandal. But New Jersey law-enforcement officials say they are nothing more than private citizens in uniform, with no law-enforcement powers. In fact, the state officials say, their presence may be illegal.

nytimes_articles.headline: Jennifer B. Lew, Paul N. Foster
nytimes_articles.abstract: Jennifer Beulah Lew, the daughter of Dr. Ellen H. Spitz of New York and Dr. John S. Lew of Ossining, N.Y., was married yesterday to Paul Nathan Foster, a son of Dorothy and Stanley Foster of Atlanta. Rabbi Albert Goldstein officiated at the Rockport (Mass.) Country Club.   Ms. Lew, 27, is keeping her name. She is the counsel to the Tobacco Products Liability Project at Northeastern University in Boston. She and her husband both graduated from Yale University, and she received a law degree from the State University at Buffalo. Her father is a consultant in applied mathematics to the computer and medical industries. Her mother is a lecturer in the psychiatry department at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center.

nytimes_articles.headline: Lori S. Brenner And Jay Sellinger
nytimes_articles.abstract: Lori Sue Brenner, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Morton R. Brenner of Boynton Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Jay Sellinger, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Sellinger of White Plains. Rabbi Murray Grauer performed the ceremony at the Brae Burn Country Club in Purchase, N.Y.   Mrs. Sellinger is a gemologist at M. Fabrikant & Sons, a jewelry concern in New York. She graduated from Washington University. Her father, who was an endodontist in New York, was also an assistant clinical professor and the chief of endodontics at Mount Sinai Hospital and Medical Center in New York.

nytimes_articles.headline: Is Clinton Moving to Left, Right or Center?; Cheer Gergen On
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Dismissing the David Gergen appointment as White House communications director as unmasked cynicism ignores Mr. Gergen's philosophical journey of the last 24 months, seen on public television's nightly news. Watching Bill Clinton progress through the primaries to the election and victory, and reporting on those events, Mr. Gergen moved from deep skepticism about the Clinton candidacy to something close to cautious endorsement, as he moved further from identification with the Bush camp.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Shopping Spree to Be The (Only) Lady in Red
nytimes_articles.abstract: They're under age, overdressed and spending incredible amounts of money. Ah, romance. It's prom night, and some of the most glamorous couples out on the town are 17 years old.    Nobody has to tell them about real life; they live here, remember? But for one night, they could dress up and pretend it was 1953. She wore something supremely sophisticated, and he showed up with flowers for his best girl.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: "I have AIDS," begins an article in the current issue of The New Yorker. The author is HAROLD BRODKEY , a writer at the magazine who is known for his intensely autobiographical fiction. In the article, Mr. Brodkey reflects on his childhood, his relationships and his career -- all discussed against the backdrop of an infection that he is publicly acknowledging for the first time.   Mr. Brodkey, 62, broke into literary circles in the late 1950's with an acclaimed book of short stories and was hailed by some critics as an American Proust or Joyce. But it took him 27 years to complete his first novel, the 835-page "Runaway Soul," which was published in 1991.

nytimes_articles.headline: Johnson Is Iron Man Of Chicago Marathon
nytimes_articles.abstract: Kevin Johnson was tired before the game. He was tired of being identified as the principal flop of the first two playoff games in Phoenix.   Johnson was tired after the game, too. He was exhausted from playing 62 minutes, the most ever played in a National Basketball Association final-round game. But he felt much better than he might have because the Suns defeated the home team, 129-121, in the triple-overtime marathon dance that more or less brought the Suns back into this series.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. Plans Tougher Strategy To Combat Alien Smuggling
nytimes_articles.abstract: Shaken by the stranding of nearly 300 illegal Chinese immigrants aboard a tramp steamer off New York last week, after a surge of similar smuggling attempts along the coasts of Florida and California, Federal officials say they are developing an arsenal of new counter-smuggling tactics.   Under a sweeping plan being devised by the National Security Council and several Federal agencies, law-enforcement officials would be armed with some of the powerful tools now widely used against organized crime but banned in immigration cases: wiretaps, far-reaching conspiracy statutes and forfeiture laws to seize money and property obtained through smuggling.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Rock; Magical Memory Tour, Complete With Updates
nytimes_articles.abstract: For the first third of Paul McCartney's show at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., on Friday night, the audience seemed shellshocked. Mr. McCartney and the Beatles mean so much to so many people that the hush that greeted him between songs felt like a result of a reconciliation of the private experience of the Beatles' music -- listening to the records at home as a backdrop to adolescence -- and the public experience of sitting at a sold-out stadium.   The contradictions between one's memories of the material and its presentation in a stadium were jarring; much of the Beatles' music was a pure product of the recording studio, irreproducible in concert. It didn't help much that a third of the way into the concert, Mr. McCartney magically metamorphosed from a Beatle into an Elton John act-alike, sentimental, and willing to turn the personal into a spectacle of amiability, hardly the original intent of the music.

nytimes_articles.headline: G.O.P. Plan Junks Truce Over Budget
nytimes_articles.abstract: An election-year budget truce between Gov. Jim Florio and the Legislature was broken this weekend, as Republican lawmakers outlined plans to earmark $150 million in the budget to soften an anticipated increase in the Federal gasoline tax by the Clinton Administration, and Mr. Florio led Democrats in attacking the proposal.   The plan is part of a $15.4 billion budget that the Republicans, who control both chambers of the Legislature, will introduce on Monday, according to Assembly Speaker Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian of Hackettstown.

nytimes_articles.headline: It Sure Quacks Like a Filibuster
nytimes_articles.abstract: It's now apparent that Senate Republicans have two overriding goals with respect to the campaign-financing reform bill now before their chamber -- neither positive. They want to kill it or, failing that, weaken it and thus reduce its threat to the political status quo. They hope to do so without being seen as obstructionist, which could hurt them with gridlock-fatigued constituents back home.   The game won't work. If serious political reform dies in the Senate, the Republican fingerprints will be apparent to everyone. So will the timidity and hypocrisy of five swing G.O.P. Senators: Dave Durenberger of Minnesota, James Jeffords of Vermont, John McCain of Arizona, William Cohen of Maine and John Chafee of Rhode Island.

nytimes_articles.headline: Politics Mixes With Salsa On Fifth Ave.
nytimes_articles.abstract: Celebrating the 500th anniversary of the Spanish arrival on Puerto Rico and their growing prominence in New York City's new political world, hundreds of thousands of Puerto Ricans filled Fifth Avenue with shouts and salsa yesterday afternoon, as local politicians of every origin competed for their handshakes and their votes.   To a mix of raucous cheers and rumbling boos, Mayor David N. Dinkins and his rival Rudolph W. Giuliani -- each dressed in the uniform of the day, crisp embroidered guayaberas that soon wilted under a brilliant sun -- marched with prominent Puerto Rican seconds, mindful that all the recent polls have shown Hispanic voters shaping up as perhaps the key swing bloc in this fall's election.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Dance; Ballet Theater's Wide-Ranging Finale
nytimes_articles.abstract: American Ballet Theater closed its season over the weekend with flags flying, offering first-rate performances in a series of debuts and in the engagement's fleeting glimpse of Antony Tudor's "Undertow."   All three ballets on the company's final bill, presented on Friday night and repeated on Saturday afternoon and evening at the Metropolitan Opera House, were created in the 1940's. Yet their amazing variety testifies to the strong esthetic differences that coexisted among choreographers in that period.

nytimes_articles.headline: Tuxedo and Gown Parade Gets Approval and a Lift
nytimes_articles.abstract: They're under age, overdressed and spending incredible amounts of money. Ah, romance. It's prom night, and some of the most glamorous couples out on the town are 17 years old.    Nobody has to tell them about real life; they live here, remember? But for one night, they could dress up and pretend it was 1953. She wore something supremely sophisticated, and he showed up with flowers for his best girl.

nytimes_articles.headline: Put More Women on a Pedestal
nytimes_articles.abstract:
Back at the turn of the century, as Susan B. Anthony entered her 80th year, a colleague in the suffrage wars broached the delicate subject of a memorial after her death. She proposed placing a statue of the distinguished women's rights leader in a park near the Anthony home in Rochester, N.Y.

Miss Anthony, as she was known, demurred. "I never can bear to see the statue of a woman exposed to the cold and rain and snow," she explained. "And I don't like to think of one of myself out of doors."

nytimes_articles.headline: Save a Planet, Make a Buck: The 'Green' Industry Ripens
nytimes_articles.abstract: Adrian Gerstel likes Earth General, a Brooklyn store devoted to selling only such environmentally correct goods as nontoxic cleaners, energy-efficient light bulbs and biodegradable golf tees. But she is torn between the store's high mission and its high prices.    "It's nice and clean and wholesome," said Ms. Gerstel, an architecture student. "You pay a little bit more, but it's almost worth it."

nytimes_articles.headline: First Lady Offers Doctors A 'Bargain' on Health Plan
nytimes_articles.abstract: In a speech to the American Medical Association today, Hillary Rodham Clinton proposed "a new bargain" in which the White House would limit malpractice lawsuits, relax regulation of medical laboratories and free doctors from burdensome Government supervision if the doctors supported President Clinton's effort to overhaul the nation's health-care system.   Mrs. Clinton said doctors must take the lead in cracking down on incompetence, negligence and other abuses by practicing physicians. In return, she said, the Administration will try to protect the "clinical autonomy" of doctors, reduce paperwork and remove legal obstacles to self-regulation of the medical profession.

nytimes_articles.headline: Miss Fleetwood And Mr. Paul
nytimes_articles.abstract: Carmen A. Fleetwood, a reporter in Trenton for the New Jersey bureau of The Associated Press, was married yesterday to Gordon A. Paul, a sportswriter for the Dorf Feature Service in Mountainside, N.J., whose articles appear in The Newark Star-Ledger. The Rev. Carol Burnside, an Episcopal minister, and Rabbi Shimon Barris officiated at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Dr. Harvey Fleetwood, in Upper Montclair, N.J.

nytimes_articles.headline: Christian Group Criticized As Unsound Insurance Plan
nytimes_articles.abstract: Two white Cadillacs are parked in front of the converted schoolhouse occupied by the Christian Brotherhood Newsletter, a not-for-profit charity, in this small city just west of Akron. Inside, two cooks are preparing a free lunch for the brotherhood's 60 employees.   The employees, nearly all related to Bruce E. Hawthorn, who founded the brotherhood, eat breakfast and lunch in a private dining room, visit their children in the cheerful nursery and, after work, exercise in the gymnasium.

nytimes_articles.headline: Jane Sovern, Ronald Meister
nytimes_articles.abstract: Jane Sovern, an assistant counsel at the City University of New York, was married yesterday to Ronald W. Meister, a partner of Eaton & Van Winkle, a New York law firm. Rabbi Richard Israel officiated at the Arch Restaurant in Brewster, N.Y.   Ms. Sovern, who is keeping her name, graduated from Brown University and received a law degree from Columbia University. She is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Sovern of Reston, Va. Her father is a consultant on national security issues.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Ballet; A Reprise of History At Balanchine Festival
nytimes_articles.abstract: Long before the final curtain fell at the New York State Theater on June 18, 1972, dance history had been made. That was the opening night of the New York City Ballet's first Stravinsky Festival, whose program of five choreographic works included the premieres of two masterly abstractions by George Balanchine, "Stravinsky Violin Concerto" and "Symphony in Three Movements."    Some of the excitement of that occasion was conjured up Tuesday night at the State Theater, when the company presented these two marvels as part of its Balanchine Celebration. There was also another ballet from that opening night, Balanchine's version of "Firebird." Whereas "Firebird" was virtually ignored in 1972 by balletgoers who were thunderstruck by the plotless premieres, its drama dazzled the audience on Tuesday.

nytimes_articles.headline: From Fiji To First As Singh Prevails
nytimes_articles.abstract: One of the most improbable journeys in golf hit a major destination today when Vijay Singh of Fiji won the Buick Classic by defeating Mark Wiebe on the third hole of sudden death.   After holing a 10-foot putt on the final hole of regulation, the 30-year-old Singh hit a brilliant 6-iron within 5 feet of the cup on the third playoff hole, the 444-yard 11th at the Westchester Country Club, and made the putt to win his first tournament on the PGA Tour.

nytimes_articles.headline: SHELLING BY SERBS IS SAID TO KILL 50 IN FIRST-AID CENTER
nytimes_articles.abstract: More than 50 people were reported killed today at an improvised first-aid center when Bosnian Serb forces unleashed heavy artillery barrages on Gorazde, which the United Nations designated a safe area less than two weeks ago.   The Sarajevo radio reported that the shelling had left Goradze's streets littered with bodies and that a rocket had exploded in the first-aid center, killing all 50 or so people inside. The number of deaths, if confirmed, would be among the highest in a single attack since fighting began in Bosnia in April 1992.

nytimes_articles.headline: Playoff Loser Wiebe 'Tickled' Just to Be in It
nytimes_articles.abstract: Mark Wiebe was one happy golfer despite losing the playoff in today's Buick Classic and the reason was simple: He barely made the second-round cut in the $1 million tournament.   "I'm tickled," Wiebe said shortly after losing to Vijay Singh in the third extra hole at Westchester Country Club. "I shot 75 and I'm in the playoff."

nytimes_articles.headline: CUTS IN MEDICARE DRAW OPPOSITION
nytimes_articles.abstract: Black Democrats in the House warned today that the Senate Finance Committee's plans for further cuts in Medicare spending threatened the future of President Clinton's entire budget in Congress. And a liberal Democrat in the Senate, Tom Harkin of Iowa, said he and his allies would also work to vote down any budget with Medicare cuts that they considered unfair.   But the Senate's Democratic majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, said that the Finance Committee would not only cut Medicare, the Federal health program for the elderly, in the version of the budget to be announced on Tuesday but would also make cuts elsewhere.

nytimes_articles.headline: Nigeria Bars News of Presidential Election Results
nytimes_articles.abstract: Uncertainty surrounded the outcome of the presidential election in Nigeria as the Government barred news organizations from reporting results of the voting.    The National Electoral Commission said final results would be released only when totals from all 30 states had been delivered to election officials in Abuja, the capital, a process that could take two or three more days. There were approximately 39 million eligible voters.

nytimes_articles.headline: Is Clinton Moving to Left, Right or Center?
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "A History of Gergenism" (editorial, June 2 ), on the ascendancy of style over substance in the Clinton White House with the appointment of David R. Gergen as communications director, was a welcome relief from mass media hype over Mr. Gergen.

nytimes_articles.headline: Lisa E. Javitch and Louis H. Benjamin
nytimes_articles.abstract: Lisa E. Javitch, a doctoral candidate in English education at Columbia University, was married yesterday to Louis H. Benjamin, a lawyer in New York. Rabbi Irving Greenberg officiated at the home of the bride's father in Harrision, N.Y.   Ms. Javitch, who is keeping her name, is an instructor of English education at Columbia University Teachers College in New York. She graduated cum laude from Macalester College and received a master's degree in literature from New York University and a master's degree in English education from Teachers College. She is the daughter of Beth Ann Segal of Wayzata, Minn., and Lee Javitch. Her father, now retired, was the chairman and chief executive in Carlisle, Pa., of Giant Food Stores Inc., which operates a chain of supermarkets.

nytimes_articles.headline: Judge's Friends Try to Save Candidacy for High Court
nytimes_articles.abstract: As President Clinton found himself enveloped for the fourth time in questions over a job candidate's household help, Judge Stephen G. Breyer's Senate backers today began an all-out drive to save his candidacy for the Supreme Court.   Led by Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Judge Breyer's chief patron in the Senate, several who had supported the 54-year-old judge, including the Senate's Republican leader, Bob Dole, said Judge Breyer should not be disqualified as a Supreme Court candidate over the disclosure that he had not paid Social Security taxes on the wages of his part-time housekeeper.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Opera; Death Visits a Dissonant Family In a New Work by David Carlson
nytimes_articles.abstract: "The Midnight Angel," David Carlson's new piece at the Opera Theater of St. Louis, addresses with considerable sophistication a contemporary genre best described as parlor melodrama.   Its themes are not Verdi's: noble factions in conflict, treachery on a regal scale or the extravagance of great love denied. We attend instead the frictions common to families: the overbearing patriarch, the dependent nephew, the lovesick niece, a world-weary family friend or two, the looming inheritance. Cheek by jowl in drawing rooms of varying splendor, such characters pour out a counterpoint of mutual resentment or isolate their sorrows in lonely asides. Lady Neville's palace in this particular opera is no parlor, but the familial dissonance that bounces along its walls is familiar indeed.

nytimes_articles.headline: Chongqing Journal; Some Chinese Won't Toe Party's Line on History
nytimes_articles.abstract: On a lush hillside here is a museum that has it all: Torture Cave with iron rods heating ominously in a fire, an American-inspired concentration camp, grisly photographs of corpses, and a riveting sound-and-light show of Communist heroes being massacred in 1949.   The museum is a reminder that the Government stays in power not only by constructing prisons, but also by building history.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. to Merge Its International Radio Operations
nytimes_articles.abstract: After months of acrimonious debate over the future of Government-sponsored broadcasting, the Clinton Administration has decided to merge all international radio operations, senior officials said this weekend.   The officials said the gradual-consolidation plan, which they expect to announce this week, would save about $250 million over the next few years and put Voice of America and Radio Free Europe-Radio Liberty under the same governing board.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bridge
nytimes_articles.abstract: For players with more ambition than experience, the Grand National Teams Flight C, for those below life master rank, offers a rare opportunity: By heading the field in New York City and Long Island, Dick and Karen Berbig, Karen Famera and Lew Kroll, all of Farmingdale, L.I., earned a trip to Washington next month to compete in national playoffs.   In the final, played a week ago at the Manhattan Club, 27 West 72d Street, they won by by 25 imps against a group led by Stan Sterenberg of Manhattan, and were aided by the diagramed deal.

nytimes_articles.headline: Selling 'Jurassic': The Film And Toys
nytimes_articles.abstract: Yes, "Jurassic Park" drew record crowds over the weekend. Yes, this Steven Spielberg dinosaur fantasy may be too violent and frightening for most children.   Rarely has the gulf between a studio's merchandising and promotion, which are heavily aimed at children, and a film, which is inappropriate for many youngsters, seemed so evident.

nytimes_articles.headline: RESULTS PLUS
nytimes_articles.abstract: TENNIS  Stich's Victory Like Watching Grass Grow  Michael Stich showed how dull winning on grass courts can be as he beat Wayne Ferreira, 6-3, 6-4, yesterday to win the Queen's Club championship in London. The sixth-seeded Stich served up seven aces in beating the defending champion and claiming the $86,000 winner's check in the warmup for Wimbledon. The two big servers seemed headed for a tie breaker in the first set until Stich dug out a superb cross-court return in the eighth game. Ferreira, seeded seventh, then volleyed long on break point to fall behind, 5-3. Stich then served out the first set. Ferreira, who was also Stich's doubles partner in the tournament, started the second set with a double-fault and was broken by two blistering backhand returns. Stich raced to a 5-1 lead before being broken for the only time, then rebounded with two aces to close out the 57-minute victory. (AP) Boetsch Gets First Victory: Arnaud Boetsch of France rallied to beat Wally Masur of Australia, 3-6, 6-3, 6-3, in the championship of the Continental grass court championships in Rosmalen, the Netherlands. The eighth-seeded Boetsch, the 29th-ranked player in the world, earned his first ATP Tour tournament victory and became the first Frenchman to win a grass-court event since Henri Leconte in Sydney, Australia, in 1985. (AP)

nytimes_articles.headline: Exit, NATO
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Western alliance is dead.   It seems likely that history will record the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's failure to respond effectively to the Bosnian war as evidence of the demise of this military and political partnership.

nytimes_articles.headline: Who Gets Health Care? Make a List.
nytimes_articles.abstract:
The Clinton Administration holds out the promise of lower medical costs, universal access, in-home care, nursing home coverage and a continued private insurance industry. But it has played down the obvious need for a system of rationing expensive treatment. In doing so, it has left a painful truth unsaid: Rationing is not just an economic issue. Rationing is also about ethics. In reforming medicine, we must address how physicians will ethically deny the best medical resources to some patients. 

Should unrepentent alcoholics get quarter-million-dollar liver transplants? Or, in a society that considers alcholism a disease, would it be discrimination to deny them one?

nytimes_articles.headline: 1893: Cancer Research : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: LONDON - So large a number of well-known members of English society are just now afflicted with cancer that it is proposed to make an exhaustive examination into the statistics of this terrible disease, in order to trace the cause of this general increase

nytimes_articles.headline: Emigres Are Holding Off on Their Hopes for Haiti
nytimes_articles.abstract: As they do most every day, Creole-speaking men and women gathered yesterday in New York City's barbershops and restaurants, on stoops and street corners, and engaged in a favorite pastime -- exchanging news from Haiti and debating oh-so-passionately the latest twist in the island politics.   But yesterday the conversations lasted a bit longer. The debate grew louder and arms gesticulated wildly as if added energy might help them make sense of a week filled with double-edged victories, tragedies and enduring frustration over their country's longstanding political turmoil.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Opera; A 'Cinderella' in St. Louis Unites Lean Sets and Luxurious Voices
nytimes_articles.abstract: Written at the turn of the century and popular during its early years, "Cinderella" (nee "Cendrillon") had a rare revival at Loretto-Hilton Center on Saturday afternoon. Massenet's setting invites spectacle on both the visual and the vocal scale. The Opera Theater of St. Louis has responded by avoiding the first and embracing the second.   Using a bare brick wall as background and a stage that reaches into the small audience space, Neil Peter Jampolis's design creates spectacle by inference. Portraits are hung and sconces attached. Lighting projections designed by Christopher Akerlind imply grand staircases, towering ballroom spaces or leafy arbors. Such parsimony is turned to musical advantage, directing our attention to the displays of singing on which the opera's uneven virtues ultimately depend.

nytimes_articles.headline: Ferreting Out False Claims For Welfare
nytimes_articles.abstract: When Vanessa F. needed money for the security deposit on a new apartment, she thought she had a foolproof solution: welfare fraud.   "I thought it would be pretty easy to do," Vanessa said. "A lot of people do it by going to the different towns and giving different addresses. A lot of them have jobs too."

nytimes_articles.headline: Earth's Crust Sinks Deep, Only to Rise in Plumes of Lava
nytimes_articles.abstract: GEOPHYSICISTS have recently made striking progress in understanding the mechanism of the great heat engine within the earth. Over the last several months they have reached a rough consensus that the vast plates that comprise the ocean floor sink deep into the earth's mantle, only to be recycled into giant ascending plumes of hot rock. The plumes, driven, some believe, by heat from the earth's core, emerge to form strings of oceanic islands like the Hawaiian chain or to blanket continents with huge sheets of lava.   The discoveries, said Dr. Michael E. Wysession, a professor at Washington University in St. Louis who is an authority on the earth's interior, constitute "a second revolution," comparable in scientific terms to the theory of plate tectonics, which, when it came to be accepted three decades ago, showed that the continents had been in constant motion over the course of geological time, carried along by great plates.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bridge Toll Divides City Of New York
nytimes_articles.abstract: A seemingly simple dispute over tolls on the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge has pitted Staten Island against the rest of the city, and is likely to be decided by Congress.   Since 1987, the majestic bridge between Staten Island and the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn has been something of an anomaly. It is the only New York City bridge where tolls are collected only from vehicles headed in one direction, specifically, from cars and trucks driving west to Staten Island.

nytimes_articles.headline: Music Notes; 2 New Competitions For Standout Pianists; No Prodigies, Please
nytimes_articles.abstract: Maurizio Pollini and Ivo Pogorelich thrive at opposite ends of the pianistic spectrum, the one taking a more cerebral, philosophical view, the other given to impulsive and often rather provocative recasting. But one thing they have in common is that their careers began at the International Chopin Piano Competition in Warsaw. Mr. Pollini won the contest in 1960. Twenty years later, Mr. Pogorelich made headlines when his elimination before the final round caused a ruckus among the jurors. Mr. Pogorelich ended up far better known than that year's winner, the Vietnamese pianist Dang Thai Son.    Mr. Pollini and Mr. Pogorelich are about to have something else in common: both are involved with new piano competitions, and both are hoping, against the odds, that they can identify pianists who will stand out in the already overcrowded field of contest winners. Both contests have unusual rules and requirements.

nytimes_articles.headline: Conference Ends With Little Hope For AIDS Cure
nytimes_articles.abstract: Only an eternal optimist would have left the ninth international AIDS meeting here last week believing that new drugs will be available anytime soon to save the lives of the 14 million people now infected with the virus that causes AIDS. Or believing that a vaccine would be developed in time to prevent the number of those infected from soaring to at least 30 million by the year 2000, as the World Health Organization predicts.   A realist, on the other hand, would be heeding the one clear message sounded at the meeting: prevention is the only way to stop the alarming spread of the virus, H.I.V., throughout the world.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Tall Order for 7-6 Bradley
nytimes_articles.abstract: The tears of a 7-foot-6-inch center fall farther and harder. Shawn Bradley, two weeks ago and about 20 time zones away in Australia, curled into a fetal position, wrinkled the suit coat he wore 24 hours a day, stared at a vaulted ceiling two inches from his forehead and cried.   "You don't want to go, do you?" said his Mormon companion.

nytimes_articles.headline: Critic's Notebook; Return of the B Movie, Now Playing on TV
nytimes_articles.abstract: Postwar 1940's. The Bronx. Within a three-block radius of my childhood apartment, there were six movie theaters, all showing second features, sometimes even third features. None of the low-budget flicks were likely to win awards, but many have become celebrated film-noir classics, the kind that always seem to star Dan Duryea.   Today. Across the nation. The second feature is virtually extinct in movie houses. Ah, but there is television. The B movie lives. And it positively thrives on one electronic equivalent of an old movie palace: the USA cable network.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Supporting Role Only : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: The United States should support Europe in Bosnia, but it cannot and should not lead. .The United States properly led the Western world in defending against the global threat of Soviet nuclear and conventional power; the United States had a vital inter

nytimes_articles.headline: THE SUPREME COURT: News Analysis -- The 11th-Hour Scramble; After Hoping for a 'Home Run' in Choosing A Justice, Clinton May Be Just Home Free
nytimes_articles.abstract: Last March, when President Clinton was presented with the opportunity to make his first Supreme Court selection, he told aides he wanted to take his time, hit a "home run" with his nominee, and choose someone who would make everyone stand up and say, "Wow."   But what was supposed to have been one of the most personally exciting decisions of Mr. Clinton's early Presidency in the end had the appearance of an 11th-hour scramble, with the bodies of other would-be nominees left strewn on the field and three months' careful deliberations boiled down to 36 hours of rapid-fire decisions.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. Warns Rulers on Vote
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Clinton Administration warned civilian and military leaders of the Cambodian Government today that they face international censure if they fail to abide by the results of the elections.    "There will be strong adverse international reaction to any effort to subvert the results of the election," said Joseph Snyder, a State Department spokesman. Mr. Snyder, however, declined to specify what kind of international response would follow if the Government of Hun Sen continues its refusal to accept the results of the election.

nytimes_articles.headline: Ozzie Canseco Retires
nytimes_articles.abstract: OZZIE CANSECO has retired from the Class AAA Louisville Redbirds.   Canseco, the twin brother of JOSE CANSECO, cited displeasure with the Redbirds' parent team, the St. Louis Cardinals, in announcing his retirement Saturday night. The 28-year-old outfielder was placed on the voluntary retired list.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Met Opera in the Parks, and Free
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Metropolitan Opera's annual series of free outdoor concerts opens tonight (Thursday in case of rain) with Puccini's "Madama Butterfly," at 8 o'clock on the Great Lawn in Central Park. The series will offer a total of four performances of "Butterfly" and four of Donizetti's "Elisir d'Amore," in all five boroughs and in parks in New Jersey.   Other performances will take place at Prospect Park, Brooklyn ("Elisir," June 16); Cunningham Park, Jamaica, Queens ("Butterfly," June 18); Great Kills Park, New Dorp, S.I. ("Elisir," June 19); Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx ("Butterfly," June 22); Brookdale Park, Montclair, N.J. ("Elisir," June 23); Waterloo Village, Stanhope, N.J. ("Butterfly," June 25), and Cooper River Park, Pennsauken, N.J. ("Elisir," June 26).

nytimes_articles.headline: THE SUPREME COURT: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices to Decide if a Federal Law Protects Abortion Clinics From Protests
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Supreme Court today agreed to decide whether abortion clinics can invoke a Federal racketeering law to sue anti-abortion groups that organize demonstrations and blockades intended to shut down the clinics.   The Justices accepted an appeal filed by the National Organization for Women, which tried to use the law, the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, to sue several anti-abortion groups on behalf of abortion clinics in Delaware and Wisconsin. The organization sought to prove that the groups had formed a nationwide conspiracy to eliminate access to abortion by using extortion and intimidation to drive the clinics out of business.

nytimes_articles.headline: Q&A
nytimes_articles.abstract: Drinking Sea Water   Q. What do birds who spend long periods at sea use for drinking water?    A.  Some seabirds, like petrels, albatrosses, gulls, terns and sea ducks, have salt-secreting glands that filter out salt from the blood so the birds can drink sea water without harm, according to the "Manual of Ornithology," by Noble S. Proctor and Patrick J. Lynch (Yale University Press).

nytimes_articles.headline: No Headline
nytimes_articles.abstract: "The announcement the President just made is significant, I believe, because it contributes to the end of the days when women, at least half the talent pool in our society, appear in high places only as one-at-a-time performers." -- JUDGE RUTH BADER GINSBURG.  [ A24:4. ]

nytimes_articles.headline: To Defend the Country : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: I suspect I wasn't the only reader angered by Mr. McCarthy's column. His comments about military people made me think about my life on military installations: how neighbors welcomed our arrival, how my wife can take evening walks without fear. I know of n

nytimes_articles.headline: Classical Music in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: 'Postcard From Morocco'  Reimann Opera Theater New York University Theater    Theatrical absurdism has lost much of its bite nowadays, largely because it has been outstripped by reality. Dominick Argento's one-act opera of 1971, "Postcard From Morocco," presents seven characters in search of identity, waiting for a train in Morocco, and they certainly speak and carry on weirdly. But have you spent any time in Penn Station lately?

nytimes_articles.headline: New Assembly Gives Prince Sihanouk Broad Powers
nytimes_articles.abstract: The newly elected National Assembly met today for the first time and immediately voted to provide Prince Norodom Sihanouk, Cambodia's ceremonial head of state and its former monarch, with all of the powers necessary "to save our nation" in the face of a secessionist threat and a continuing civil war.    While Prince Sihanouk did not immediately accept the wide-ranging powers offered to him by the 120-member assembly, the vote was proof of his indispensable role in international efforts to restore peace to this shattered country.

nytimes_articles.headline: Two Groups, Citing Savings, Urge Privatization of City Jobs
