nytimes_articles.abstract: Asserting that New York City is mired in a prolonged fiscal crisis, two prominent business groups proposed yesterday that the city turn over some services to private companies and take other broad steps that they said would reduce spending and increase revenue by nearly $16 billion over the next 10 years.   The groups, the New York City Partnership and the New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry, acknowledged that their plan, which also includes putting tolls on the East River bridges, relied on ideas that have been under consideration for decades.

nytimes_articles.headline: Hidden Economy: Immigrants Underground -- Third of six articles.; Few Emigres Can Fight Mistreatment on the Job
nytimes_articles.abstract: Last August, when K. Shah worked at a construction site renovating brownstones in Brooklyn, he complained to his bosses that he was suffering shooting pains in his arm. The illegal Pakistani immigrant, assigned to heave 70-pound concrete blocks from the sidewalk to the fifth floor using a rudimentary block and tackle, was told to keep quiet and keep working.   Two days later, Mr. Shah, 37, suffered a heart attack on the job. It felt like his chest was on fire, he said. Reluctantly, after warning him not to tell hospital officials where he worked, his bosses allowed him to leave and take a subway to North Central Bronx Hospital. Two weeks later, he underwent bypass surgery.

nytimes_articles.headline: METRO DIGEST
nytimes_articles.abstract: EMIGRES STRUGGLE AGAINST MISTREATMENT   Although the city's growing underground economy provides jobs and opportunities for some, it condemns an increasing number of immigrants to a life of ever-worsening exploitation. A1.  NEW YORK CITY  BUDGET IS PASSED BY CITY COUNCIL   After nearly 12 hours of hearings and debate, the City Council formally passes a $31.2 billion budget package. B3.

nytimes_articles.headline: Freudians Didn't Part Amiably With Masson
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   A June 4 front-page article reports two statements Jeffrey M. Masson made about me that I wish to correct.   (1) When the board of the Sigmund Freud Archives, of which I was director, decided to discontinue Dr. Masson's appointment as program director, I am alleged to have remarked, "Who knows that in a few years if we don't bring you back?" -- thus holding out the possibility of a future appointment. But it is utterly impossible that I ever said anything of the kind, and it stands to reason that the archives' board could never maintain an official connection of any kind with anyone who without adequate cause publicly denounced Freud.

nytimes_articles.headline: To Surf and Ski, the Japanese Are Heading Indoors
nytimes_articles.abstract: Beachgoing season is here and Norio Tsubokawa is sitting on the sand by the water's edge with his wife and daughter, watching body surfers ride the waves. It is a typical summer scene except for a few details -- the "sand" is made from concrete and rubber, the waves are made by machine and the entire "beach" and "ocean" are inside a huge building.   Wild Blue Yokohama, complete with plastic palm trees, is one of several indoor beaches that have recently opened or are being built in Japan. In a nation where most of the natural coastline has been paved over or filled in, and where the great outdoors is hard to reach from the big cities, people can now experience what might be called the "great indoors" instead.

nytimes_articles.headline: RESULTS PLUS
nytimes_articles.abstract: TENNIS  Chang Exits Early  Michael Chang's final tuneup for Wimbledon ended abruptly yesterday when he was beaten, 6-3, 3-6, 6-3, by Bernd Karbacher in the first round of the grass-court tournament in Halle, Germany. The event also marks Andre Agassi's return from a two-month layoff from right wrist problems. Agassi practiced in private for 25 minutes before rain halted his workout. He will play Carl-Uwe Steeb of Germany today. Karbacher's victory was his third in three meetings -- and second in three weeks -- against Chang, who is seeded third at Halle. The German defeated Chang in the second round of the French Open. Yesterday, Karbacher broke Chang in the eighth game en route to winning the first set and again after falling behind by 2-0 in the second set. Chang rallied to win that set, but another break by Karbacher in the final set spurred him to victory and brought Chang's warmup for Wimbledon to an abrupt end. (AP)   Sprinkles in Manchester: Henrik Holm of Sweden and Nicolas Pereira of Venezuela were the only winners yesterday when rain cut short the opening day of play at the Manchester grass-court tournament in England. Holm, seeded second, dropped the first set against Brett Steven of New Zealand before rebounding to win, 3-6, 7-5, 6-4. Pereira needed three sets and two tie breakers to beat Alex O'Brien of Amarillo, Tex., 6-7 (6-8), 6-3, 7-6 (7-4). Five other singles matches were postponed until today, and qualifying rounds for the doubles competition were moved indoors. Holm will next face either his countryman Anders Jarryd or Luis Herrera of Mexico. Pereira, the world's top-ranked junior in 1988, will meet either eighth-seeded Guillaume Raoux of France or Gianluca Pozzi of Italy.  (AP)

nytimes_articles.headline: When Doctors Used to Talk to Patients
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   The insurance of medical care has had a number of unintended results, the major one being a vast explosion of demand for medical care, because it is paid for by other people's money, that is, medical insurance claim reimbursement. I have observed another unintended result. Since medical insurance reimburses doctors far more for procedures than for spending time listening to and talking to patients about their illnesses, many doctors have, where possible, shifted to an increased use of procedures. There are many legitimate reasons for this -- for instance, new technology and fear of malpractice suits for not using the latest tools available.

nytimes_articles.headline: Needed: More High School Graduates
nytimes_articles.abstract: Good news: For the third year in a row, more New York City students are staying in school and not dropping out. But there's a catch. Even after spending up to seven years in high school, fewer than 60 percent of students receive a diploma. That poses a real test of Schools Chancellor Joseph Fernandez's theory that students are more likely to succeed in smaller high schools. It also poses a challenge to his successor: to push the graduation rate up while keeping the dropout rate down.    Deciphering New York's dropout rate has become an annual ritual. In the early 1980's it was calculated to be as high as 42 percent. Since 1986, however, the Board of Education has tracked through graduation the entire group of students entering ninth grade each year. That at least has made year-to-year comparisons uniform.

nytimes_articles.headline: And Now A Message From Mets' Youngsters
nytimes_articles.abstract: Play the kids. Get dirty. Let hunger loose. Three months ago, the Mets derided the notions as empty advertisements that couldn't cut it in New York. But now, the unthinkable has become the unavoidable, their roster stocked more with the raw than the rich.   Maybe it won't win much. But it might sell. It's not a bad bargain for the Mets to strike at the moment.

nytimes_articles.headline: Chess
nytimes_articles.abstract: When opponents prepare to march against your position, the natural reaction is to stop them. Yet sometimes there is another way. Quite often a great player like Samuel Reshevsky would allow his opponents to carry out their plans and then deviously demonstrate that there were hidden defects he could exploit. One psychological advantage of this strategy is that opponents will not easily apply the brakes to their pet schemes, even supposing they have a hunch you are up to something.   The game between the grandmasters Bent Larsen of Denmark and Gata Kamsky of Brooklyn from Round 10 of the Fourth Miguel Najdorf International Tournament in Buenos Aires shows the 19-year-old American nicely carrying out the Reshevsky stratagem. His victory in this encounter helped him tie for first place with the Latvian grandmaster Aleksei Shirov, each with 7-4 scores in the event, which was held April 18 to 30 to celebrate Najdorf's 83d birthday. Third place went to Viktor Korchnoi at 6 1/2-4 1/2.

nytimes_articles.headline: THE SUPREME COURT: The Overview; CLINTON NAMES RUTH GINSBURG, ADVOCATE FOR WOMEN, TO COURT
nytimes_articles.abstract: President Clinton today chose Judge Ruth Bader Ginsburg, whose litigation on behalf of women's rights helped transform the legal landscape in the 1970's, to become the first Supreme Court Justice picked by a Democratic President in 26 years.   If confirmed, Judge Ginsburg, whose first job out of Columbia University Law School was as a legal secretary, would be the second woman to serve on the High Court, joining Justice Sandra Day O'Connor. She would also be the first Jew to serve on the Court since Justice Abe Fortas resigned in 1969. Unpredictable Center    In her 13 years on the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, the 60-year-old Brooklyn-born judge has occupied an unpredictable center on a panel that has grown into rigidly hostile ideological camps. She has ruled in favor of abortion rights, but has also criticized the 1973 Supreme Court decision that made abortion a Constitutional right, saying it went too far, too fast.

nytimes_articles.headline: Can U.N. Survive Continued Failure in Bosnia?; Germany's Blame
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Re "Germany Is Not to Blame for Bosnia" by David C. Unger (Editorial Notebook, June 7): I cannot understand omission of the vital fact that diplomatic recognition of Bosnia was extended after the recognition of Slovenia and Croatia in December 1991.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Cabaret; The Belter as Balladeer
nytimes_articles.abstract: Laurie Beechman is a performer bursting with such heart that in almost everything she sings there is the sense of someone emotionally attempting to shoot the moon. The singer, who is appearing at Rainbow and Stars through July 3, has the voice to back up that drive. When singing quietly, she projects a smoky, yearning intensity. Pushing up the volume, she becomes a piercing belter who could almost shatter glass in phrases that turn around a maudlin, full-throated sob.    What Ms. Beechman, who has performed in clubs for many years, is slowly coming to learn is that for someone with a voice and emotive instincts as large as hers, less is more. The best moments at Thursday's early show were relatively quiet renditions of "Isn't It Romantic?" and "Long Before I Knew You," in which she held back the sob and sang at half-throttle. Her version of "A Very Precious Love," the stately Paul Webster-Sammy Fain ballad from the movie "Marjorie Morningstar" skillfully blended the soft and the aggressive.

nytimes_articles.headline: THE SUPREME COURT: The News Media; After a Bid for a Truce, the White House and the Press Corps Are Back at It
nytimes_articles.abstract: It took about 18 hours for President Clinton's tentatively declared second honeymoon with the White House press corps to collapse in a heap.   On Sunday night, Bill and Hillary Clinton invited hundreds of journalists to a picnic on the South Lawn of the White House that featured badminton, volleyball and an amateur stage revue mounted by the White House communications staff.

nytimes_articles.headline: Reviews/Dance; A Modernist 'Coppelia,' With Balanchine's Touch
nytimes_articles.abstract: "Coppelia," one of the greatest of all comic ballets, was originally choreographed by Arthur Saint-Leon in Paris in 1870. It was later offered in a revised form by Marius Petipa in St. Petersburg in 1884. On Sunday night, the New York City Ballet presented it as part of its Balanchine Celebration at the New York State Theater.    It did not seem out of place in a tribute to a distinguished contemporary choreographer. Yet it still resembled a 19th-century ballet. This is because when George Balanchine staged "Coppelia" for his company in 1974, he based his production upon that of Petipa and added new choreography of his own in the 19th-century style. He was assisted in this venture by Alexandra Danilova, the ballerina and ballet teacher who was one of this century's finest interpreters of Swanilda, the work's starring role. Together, they gave a sweet old ballet new life.

nytimes_articles.headline: Lao-Tzu's Tips for Clinton
nytimes_articles.abstract:
President Clinton could have saved Judge Stephen Breyer from a version of the Chinese water torture by following an ancient treatise on the art of governing, the "Tao Te Ching" or "Book of the Way." Written more than 2,000 years ago by Lao-tzu, a contemporary of Confucius, it can show Mr. Clinton the tao ("way") to repair his political fortunes.

"Hold on to the center." As a candidate, Mr. Clinton portrayed himself as a new Democrat, a moderate committed to centrist policies. "Just stay at the center of the circle," Lao-tzu wrote. "You will endure forever." Once inaugurated, Mr. Clinton veered from the center, leaving people to believe the real Bill Clinton is a donkey in sheep's clothing. Putting David Gergen in the White House and keeping Lani Guinier out of the Justice Department isn't enough to foil that suspicion.

nytimes_articles.headline: Wimbledon Seeds Agassi 8th
nytimes_articles.abstract: ANDRE AGASSI became the lowest-seeded men's defending champion in Wimbledon history yesterday, and he got a break to be seeded as high as he was.   Wimbledon's seeding committee, which often disregards ranking, seeded the 13th-ranked Agassi at No. 8. The American, who has been suffering from a right-wrist injury, is expected to play this week for the first time since April.

nytimes_articles.headline: Haitians With H.I.V. Leave Cuba Base for Lives in U.S.
nytimes_articles.abstract: They arrived at the airstrip here as the sun was rising, dressed in clothes sent them by relatives and quietly clutching their few possessions. For 27 Haitian political refugees, 20 months of confinement in what a Federal judge has described as a squalid "H.I.V. prison camp" ended today with a flight to the United States and freedom.   The departure of the group, 21 adults who are infected with the virus that causes AIDS and six children who have not been tested for the disease, was the first step toward closing the military detention center, as ordered last week by Judge Sterling Johnson Jr. of the Federal District Court in Brooklyn. Col. Raymond A. Barbeau, commander of the camp, said he expected the remaining 113 Haitian refugees to leave "in the next 10 days to two weeks."

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. Rejects Notion That Human Rights Vary With Culture
nytimes_articles.abstract: Responding to a challenge by some authoritarian governments in the third world, the United States warned today that it would oppose any attempt to use religious and cultural traditions to weaken the concept of universal human rights.   The strong statement set the stage for a intense struggle between Western countries committed to the universality of human rights and countries that oppose what they describe as the imposition of Western values.

nytimes_articles.headline: Reviews/Dance; 6-Decade Retrospective
nytimes_articles.abstract: The New Dance Group has played an important though quiet part in New York cultural history over six decades as a place for dancers to learn, teach and practice their craft. It was one of the first racially integrated dance schools and served as a home for all who saw dance as part of a larger social vision.   The New Dance Group Gala Retrospective, presented on Friday night at the theater of the Fiorello H. La Guardia High School of Music and the Arts, offered a remarkably fresh taste of that history and vision. There were telltale signs of age in a few of the pieces. But from the opening number, a hauntingly lyrical excerpt from Mary Anthony's 1956 "Songs," performed by seven members of Miss Anthony's company, the emphasis was on simplicity and an ageless craft.

nytimes_articles.headline: To Defend the Country : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Thank you for publishing Colman McCarthy's commentary on women and gays in the military. And thank you, Mr. McCarthy, for so cogently reminding us of our true priorities.

nytimes_articles.headline: World Trade Center Fire
nytimes_articles.abstract: A fire broke out at the World Trade Center yesterday, starting and ending with an air-conditioner that was installed after the bombing in February, the Fire Department said. No one was hurt and there was only minor damage. The air-conditioner, a temporary two-story unit attached to the outside of Two World Trade Center, malfunctioned and burst into flames shortly before 2 P.M., said a spokesman for the Fire Department, Capt. Ed Harrington. The fire was brought under control by 2:17, he said, so there was no need to evacuate any part of the skyscraper. But the fire was serious enough that 12 fire trucks and 55 firefighters were called to put it out.

nytimes_articles.headline: 1918:Italian Offensive : IN OUR PAGES: 100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: ROME - Today's Italian communiqué says: In the early hours of yesterday morning [June 13], after intense artillery preparation, the enemy attempted to force our defences of the Passo del Tonale, launching his infantry to the attack of our positions o

nytimes_articles.headline: Classical Music in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: Festival Ensemble Society  American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters Washington Heights    "All races have inheritances: left to their own devices, they will naturally follow their native bent. An effort from the outside to lay down rather strict lines along which their art should develop can only result in self-consciousness and, consequently, in inartistic and insincere results." These are words of R. Nathaniel Dett, a black American composer who lived from 1882 to 1943 and who dedicated himself to the preservation and musical elaboration of spirituals and folk songs. He called his mission "the emancipation of Negro music."

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Pop; Toto's Debut, With Its Hits Of the Past
nytimes_articles.abstract: Maybe it's mere coincidence that Toto made its belated New York debut just as the hype for the movie "Jurassic Park" was peaking. But nearly every song Toto played on Wednesday night at the Electric Ballroom (actually the Supper Club, minus most tables) could have been cloned from the DNA of extinct dinosaur-rock styles from the 1970's and 80's.    Toto, a group of Los Angeles studio musicians, swept the major 1983 Grammy awards thanks to hits like "Africa" and "Rosanna," then slogged along with intermittent commercial success through the 1980's. It has just released a new album, "Kingdom of Desire" (Relativity) with Simon Phillips on drums replacing Jeff Porcaro, who died in August 1992.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bridge
nytimes_articles.abstract: Some of the prettiest endings in the game are rare because they are fragile: best defense will usually make it impossible to reach the required position. An example is the first deal of the New York Regional Green Point Pairs last month, with the North-South cards held by Irina Levitina of Teaneck, N.J., and Ilya Levitin of Emerson, N.J. They are certainly one of the world's strongest sister-and-brother partnerships.   West's weird-looking two no-trump opening was a two-under pre-empt, now popular in some quarters. It showed a hand on which others might open three diamonds. East corrected to three diamonds, and South took a reasonable shot at four spades. Diamonds were led and continued, and when South ruffed he could see nine probable tricks. He did not choose to put all his eggs in the trump basket, so instead of crossing to the heart king and finessing the spade jack, he cashed his top spades in the hope that the queen would fall.

nytimes_articles.headline: Griffith Makes a Comeback
nytimes_articles.abstract: No one had ever hurt him that much in the ring. But one night late last July, Emile Griffith found himself on a sidewalk in the Times Square area, an ache in the back of his neck, his sides hurting, his pockets empty.   "I wanted to get home to Queens," he recalled last week. "But I took the D train uptown. I looked up and I saw I was at Yankee Stadium so I got out, went to the other side, and went downtown."

nytimes_articles.headline: Four Men Arrested In Protection Scheme
nytimes_articles.abstract: Four members of an Asian gang were arrested yesterday and charged with extortion and conspiracy for demanding protection money from Chinese restaurants in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, the police said.   The four young men, aged 15 to 20, were arrested on the street near Fifth Avenue and 59th Street in Brooklyn in the early afternoon, said Detective Ron Antoci of the Brooklyn Robbery Squad. All four are members of the Flying Dragons, a Chinatown gang, Detective Antoci said.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bowman to Coach Red Wings
nytimes_articles.abstract: SCOTTY BOWMAN, the coach with the most National Hockey League victories, is expected to be named coach of the Detroit Red Wings today.   His hiring has been widely reported for weeks, and the club has scheduled a news conference today at 11 A.M. Eastern time, when the appointment is to be announced. BRYAN MURRAY, Red Wings coach and general manager since coming to Detroit in 1990, will remain general manager.

nytimes_articles.headline: Can We Stop the Chinese Slave Trade?
nytimes_articles.abstract:
The boatload of illegal Chinese aliens that ran aground off Queens, together with other ships found full of hopeful immigrants, has reignited debate over the abuse of our disabled asylum system. But measures in Congress that would restrict access to political asylum and make it easier to exclude illegal immigrants are flawed. They would not significantly stem the flow and would make it harder for the many legitimate cases to get a fair hearing.

The Immigration and Naturalization Service wants us to believe today's wave of illegal immigration from China is unprecedented in scope. It is not. About 100,000 Chinese entered the U.S. illegally in 1987 and in 1991. But the I.N.S., which once cited these figures, now disowns them. It is trying to obscure the extent of immigrant smuggling from China so as to camouflage its own past failure to prevent it and to shift blame to the asylum process.

nytimes_articles.headline: Providing in Prose the Eerie Voice of Madness
nytimes_articles.abstract: Patrick McCabe is a quiet man who lobbed a small bombshell of a novel and is still reeling from the blast. Two years ago, he was teaching learning-disabled students in a London grade school, and writing a strange tale at night. It was called "The Butcher Boy," and it was a haunting narrative, told in the voice of a small-town Irish boy who descends into madness and commits an act of unspeakable violence, forshadowed in the first sentence of the book: "When I was a young lad 20 or 30 or 40 years ago I lived in a small town where they were all after me on account of what I done on Mrs. Nugent."   Lyrical and disturbing, horrific and hilarious, "The Butcher Boy" reaped a bumper harvest of critical superlatives in Britain and Ireland. As a fictional creation, Francie Brady, the narrator, was placed in the same company as Huck Finn and Holden Caulfield. The novel's language -- passionate, colloquial and rich -- was deemed worthy of Joyce.

nytimes_articles.headline: Plan for 'Safe Areas' in Bosnia May Need 7,500 More Troops
nytimes_articles.abstract: A report by Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali to the Security Council today estimated that at least 7,500 more peacekeeping troops, backed by the threat of air strikes, would be needed to deter Serbian attacks against six "safe areas" designated by the Council in Bosnia.    The report said full security -- "deterrence through strength" -- would require 34,000 more troops. But a "light option" of 7,500 troops is all that member states were likely to contribute in the foreseeable future, the report added.

nytimes_articles.headline: Trading a Badge For a Stethoscope
nytimes_articles.abstract: A little more than 24 hours after he walked up to the stage of Carnegie Hall in his cap and gown to receive his medical degree, Sgt. Michael Murray was wearing the uniform of the New York City Police Department and conducting roll call for the 6 P.M.-to-2 A.M. tour in one of the toughest precincts in the city.   "Valentin, 12 post. Twenty-two hundred meal," Sergeant Murray said. In his best Jack Webb monotone, he was assigning the night's foot posts and lunch schedule to the dozen young officers standing in the muster room of the 34th Precinct station house. The precinct, which encompasses Washington Heights, led New York City again last year in murders.

nytimes_articles.headline: Barkley Elbows Injury Aside
nytimes_articles.abstract: Charles Barkley, the Phoenix Suns' All-Star forward, said today that his right elbow was still sore, but that he expected to play Wednesday night in Game 4 of the National Basketball Association finals. Barkley had to have the elbow drained of fluid before Game 3 on Sunday night, but he played and had 24 points and 19 rebounds as the Suns beat the Bulls in triple overtime.

nytimes_articles.headline: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Regarding the report "India's Dirty New War: Chilling Tales of Atrocities From Kashmir" (June 8) by Molly Moore and John Ward Anderson: .India would be wise to restrain its seemingly uncontrollable security forces, which seem hell-bent on vic

nytimes_articles.headline: WHAT THEY'RE READING
nytimes_articles.abstract: David Mura, author of "Turning Japanese: Memoirs of a Sansei," is reading "The LeRoi Jones-Amiri Baraka Reader." ."He has worked in very different forms, starting out as a poet, as I did. I grew up with the standards of white Eu

nytimes_articles.headline: Article 454893 -- No Title
nytimes_articles.abstract: After nearly 12 hours of hearings and debate, the City Council formally passed a $31.2 billion budget package early yesterday morning, completing an unusually protracted process by ratifying an agreement reached over the weekend by Mayor David N. Dinkins and Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone.   The budget was adopted by a vote of 45 to 6, with the Council's Republican members voting against the package.

nytimes_articles.headline: For Canada's New Chief, the Fight Has Just Begun
nytimes_articles.abstract: Kim Campbell has written herself into history books with a Tory leadership triumph that makes her the first woman to serve as Canada's Prime Minister and one of only 20 women to head a national government this century. But she still faces the challenge of winning a mandate from the Canadian people.   Although she has promised Canadians "good government with thoughtful policies, honestly presented, openly arrived at, and implemented with competence and with care for every cent of your tax dollar," her honeymoon is likely to be brief.

nytimes_articles.headline: As the World Turns
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE big programs get all the attention and respect and start the hottest arguments. Here are two programs that probably will not provoke anyone to put up his dukes, but if you like them, you like them, and if you need them, you need them.   CNN Newsroom Worldclock Calendar Atlas offers views of the Earth, either as a globe or flat map; gives the local time at various spots; measures distances between two places; presents, both numerically and graphically, sunrise and sunset anywhere, and, optionally, shows latitude and longitude. It can zoom out to show the whole world, or zoom in to an area as small as a particular ZIP code, in the United States.

nytimes_articles.headline: Transactions
nytimes_articles.abstract: Baseball  American League   MILWAUKEE BREWERS -- Placed Mike Boddicker, pitcher, on the 15-day disabled list. Recalled Mike Ignasiak, pitcher, from New Orleans of the American Association.   OAKLAND ATHLETICS -- Signed Andy Smith, pitcher, and Brian Whatley, catcher.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: An article yesterday about a meeting of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops this week in New Orleans misstated the opening day. It is Thursday. The article also referred incorrectly to the bishops' scheduled action on the International Commission on English in the Liturgy. They plan to discuss the role of the commission, but not to vote on it.

nytimes_articles.headline: G.O.P. Budget Would Deny Florio a Tax Cut
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Republicans who control New Jersey's Legislature today advanced a $15.4 billion budget that would deny Gov. Jim Florio any share in providing an election-year tax cut.   Mr. Florio's re-election depends on his overcoming voters' anger over the record $2.8 billion tax increase that he pushed through in 1990 within his first six months in office. To take the onus off that memory, his administration had negotiated for weeks with Republican budget officers over using up to $100 million in surplus money to give New Jersey residents a direct cut in property taxes.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. Aircraft Again Attack Somali Faction's Arms Sites
nytimes_articles.abstract: American aircraft struck at a Somali militia's storage sites in this city for a third consecutive day today. No militia casualties were reported, but three civilians were reported wounded when a rocket apparently went awry and struck a sidewalk tea stall several hundred yards from the intended target.   The attack fed the growing anger in the capital against the United States and the United Nations. At a rally in the middle of the city, several hundred people gathered to protest the air strikes, sitting on the ground and chanting "Down With Bill Clinton!"

nytimes_articles.headline: L.T. Is on the Green and Reeves Is Seeing Red
nytimes_articles.abstract: Lawrence Taylor's personal prescription for rehabilitating his severed Achilles' tendon this spring has been at least 18 holes on a choice golf course at every available opportunity. For Giants Coach Dan Reeves, that's a bitter pill to swallow.   Today, as the Giants' three-day mini-camp started, Taylor was playing golf at a charity event in Kansas City, Mo., and Reeves reacted sharply to the fact that the star linebacker wasn't here and apparently had no plans to be here. Historically, Taylor hasn't attended mini-camps. The last one he did attend was in 1986.

nytimes_articles.headline: 'Handedness' Seen in Nature, Long Before Hands
nytimes_articles.abstract: BITE scars found in the fossils of ancient shellfish have yielded strong evidence that half a billion years ago animals had already evolved "handedness," the kind of behavior that makes most human beings favor one hand or the other.   A new study shows that certain sea creatures that evolved even before animals first colonized the land -- and long before the evolution of the hand -- persistently turned toward their favored sides when attacking prey or evading predators.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: An entry in the Finance Briefs listing in Business Day on Wednesday misstated the debt rating by Duff & Phelps for First Fidelity Bancorp's offering of $150 million in subordinated notes. The rating is BBB+.

nytimes_articles.headline: Can U.N. Survive Continued Failure in Bosnia?; The Recognition Game
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   It has recently been claimed that the "early" recognition of Croatia and Slovenia, prompted by German pressure, was the main cause of the conflict in the former Yugoslavia, including the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina. This assertion overlooks the chronological sequence of events preceding the oubreak of the war, including its root causes.

nytimes_articles.headline: On My Mind; Syria, Drugs and The U.S.
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Bekaa Valley was once Lebanon's breadbasket -- rich with wheat, fruit, vineyards. Since Syria took military control of the country 90 percent of the valley has been given over to drug cultivation -- particularly opium for heroin.   Syrian military units border cannabis and opium fields and laboratories for making the heroin. Individual Syrian officers make as much as $30,000 a year from the trade.

nytimes_articles.headline: HOUSE PANEL ADDS ABORTION BENEFITS
nytimes_articles.abstract: Without a roll call or even debate, the House Appropriations Committee voted today to include abortion in Federal employees' health-care benefits.   Approval by the full House and the Senate is considered probable and would end a Government ban on such coverage that was imposed in 1983. The House panel's action reflected a major shift in abortion policy since President Clinton took office after 12 years of Republican Administrations.

nytimes_articles.headline: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Regarding "Kashmir: Uncover Their Ugly Secret" (Opinion, May 26) by James A. Goldston and Patricia Gossman: .More than 200,000 Hindus have been driven out of their ancestral homeland in Kashmir by Muslim bandits, who are financed, armed and t

nytimes_articles.headline: Doctors Planning Battle Against Health-Care Plan
nytimes_articles.abstract: Leaders of the American Medical Association laid the groundwork today for an aggressive legal and political campaign against two important elements of the health plan being developed by President Clinton: limits on national health-care spending and on doctors' charges.   The association's board warned that there would be significant constitutional problems if the Government tried to impose price controls or an overall limit on health spending, both of which have been advocated by the White House.

nytimes_articles.headline: No Seasonal Change Found for Color Vision
nytimes_articles.abstract: FOR 45 years, scientists thought that people's color vision varied according to the seasons, and they could not understand why. Now science has come up with an answer to the mystery: the instrument used for the test in 1948 was flawed.   A study in the current issue of the journal Nature found that the instrument's readings were affected by room temperature. So if a testing room got warmer and cooler through the year, the device would seem to indicate that people's color vision varied with the seasons, researchers said.

nytimes_articles.headline: Mr. Clinton Picks a Justice
nytimes_articles.abstract: When he finally settled on a choice for Supreme Court justice, President Clinton chose one of the best sitting judges -- Ruth Bader Ginsburg, for 13 years a strong member of the U.S. Court of Appeals in Washington. She is an able jurist of moderate to liberal bent who does not frighten conservatives.    She is more besides: a pioneer lawyer for the modern movement of women toward equality under the law; a judge whose whole career, not only her gender, stands for the principle that people and ideas be accepted or rejected on their merits without prejudice or stereotypes.

nytimes_articles.headline: Some Good News for Johnson
nytimes_articles.abstract: The latest diagnosis of Howard Johnson's mysterious illness has, for the moment, ruled out any of the most alarming possibilities. Hepatitis, a fear for a while, has been discounted. Rheumatoid arthritis, not an improbablity, seems a long shot. Lyme disease has been effectively ruled out. "Is there a chance that it could still wind up a significant problem?" said Dr. John Olichney, the internist for the Mets. "Tiny. Really tiny." Johnson, who is suffering from what the medical officials are terming "an acute viral syndrome," remained in New York today, sick but relieved and recovering.

nytimes_articles.headline: Foreign Students
nytimes_articles.abstract: Foreigners accounted for approximately half of the 30,432 postdoctoral fellows in science and engineering at universities in the United States in 1991, according to a report by the National Science Foundation.    Ten years ago, they made up only one-third of the total, said Dr. J. G. Huckenpohler, a science resource analyst for the foundation.

nytimes_articles.headline: Flaws Are Seen in Diagnosis And Control of Lyme Disease
nytimes_articles.abstract: Ah, the start of summer. A time for bathing suits and cutoffs; carefree hikes in the woods; picnics in the meadow.    But this time of year, in places like northern Westchester County, people prepare to venture out into nature with the diligence of soldiers fitting up for war: pulling on long-sleeved shirts, tucking pants into socks and nervously inspecting their children each time they venture in from the yard.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: A sports chart yesterday about the United States Open golf tournament in New Jersey this week misstated ABC-TV's broadcast schedule for it. The network plans to show taped highlights on Thursday and Friday, from 11:35 P.M. to 12:05 A.M., Eastern time, and to provide live coverage on Saturday and Sunday, from 1 P.M. to 6 P.M.

nytimes_articles.headline: Former School Custodian Accused of Theft
nytimes_articles.abstract: A former school custodian who the authorities said logged hundreds of hours piloting a corporate jet when he should have been at work in a Brooklyn public school was arrested yesterday and charged with theft and falsifying records.   The former custodian, Albert Friedland, 50, of Sterling Forest, N.Y., surrendered on a 43-count indictment handed down earlier this month by a Brooklyn grand jury, and he was arraigned last night before Acting Justice Barry A. Cozier of the Supreme Court.

nytimes_articles.headline: Israel Again Offers Arabs Broader Civil Authority
nytimes_articles.abstract: With a new round of Middle East peace talks starting in Washington on Tuesday, Israel is offering to hand the Palestinians immediate control over many functions of daily life, even before an agreement is reached on self-rule in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.    While the offer is not new, some Israeli officials have focused on it with extra intensity of late as a possible quick deal that could show progress and ease the way toward resolving more complex issues involved in any future Palestinian self-government.

nytimes_articles.headline: F.D.A. Is Again Proposing to Regulate Vitamins and Supplements
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Food and Drug Administration will renew its efforts to control vitamins and other dietary supplements on Tuesday, when it announces plans to regulate health claims. The agency will also seek advice on how to assure the safety of the products in the $4 billion market.   Those plans have been met with a vigorous counterattack by the supplement industry, which opposes any new regulations.

nytimes_articles.headline: Somali Warlord, Still at Large, In a Test of Wills With U.N.
nytimes_articles.abstract: During three days of attacks, AC-130 gunships have blasted Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid's weapons sites. Cobra helicopters have attacked the Somali warlord's radio station. And today an attack helicopter demolished one of his rocket launchers.   But the United Nations forces in Somalia have yet to arrest the man who Washington has said is at the heart of the problem there.

nytimes_articles.headline: Mr. Banks, Unloved, Goes to Washington
nytimes_articles.abstract: Carl Banks traded uniforms but not road maps yesterday.   After nine seasons as a Giant, he wound up with a team he knows quite well: the Washington Redskins. The former Pro Bowl linebacker signed a three-year deal worth a total of about $5.4 million, including a bonus and salary of $2.1 million for this year.

nytimes_articles.headline: Observer; Eponymy On the Potomac
nytimes_articles.abstract: A Dictionary of Washington Eponymical Etymology:   To Bork, verb. The act of scrutinizing to death a nominee for high public office. The word derives from Robert Bork, a Supreme Court nominee whose record was examined so minutely by the Senate Judiciary Committee that the rest of the Senate, assuming there must be something wrong with anyone who needed that much scrutiny, refused to confirm him. Usage examples: "Unless Clinton nominates people acceptable to Republicans, we will Bork them in the streets, we will Bork them in the hills, and we will Bork them on C-Span." (Winston Churchill, when asked what he would say if he were to return as Senator Bob Dole.) Slang: "Stick a fork in him, he's Borked."

nytimes_articles.headline: The Virus: Threat or Menace?
nytimes_articles.abstract: IN case you missed it, Wednesday was Virus Awareness Day. Various computer industry groups went before Congress last week to testify about a growing menace of computer viruses and the need to protect the Clinton Administration's proposed "information superhighway" from viral attacks.   Although lacking in the popular appeal of other festive national commemorations like National Pickle Week, Virus Awareness Day did focus calm attention on a problem that normally suffers from too much agitated attention.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about the closing of parts of two parks in New York City because of lead contamination misattributed a quotation about why officials took the action. It was Mayor David N. Dinkins, not Stewart Desmond, a spokesman for the Parks Department, who said, referring to bridges, "While our goal is to repaint these structures with nontoxic paints to guard against future lead problems, we also need to act now to safeguard the health of children and families who use parks near bridges."

nytimes_articles.headline: In Her Own Words: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
nytimes_articles.abstract: ON WOMEN AND THE LAW    From a 1987 speech in Colorado Springs:    The Warren Court of the 1960's thus held the base line set by the Supreme Court in the 1870's, at the turn of the century, and in the 1940's. That base line tied tightly into the prevailing "separate spheres" mentality, or breadwinner-homemaker dichotomy: It was man's lot, because of his nature, to be breadwinner, head of the household, representative of the family outside the home; and it was woman's lot, because of her nature, not only to bear but also to raise children, and keep the home in order.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Mansion Out of Place, And Maybe Out of Time
nytimes_articles.abstract: JOSEPH MIRABELLA'S family is only the second to live in the old mansion on the corner of Martin Luther King Boulevard. The way things look, it will also be the last.   A big yellow "For Sale" sign hangs conspicuously on the black wrought-iron fence that has protected the four-story brick building since 1906. But no one expects a family that can afford to pay $695,000 to spend it on a place surrounded by tenement houses and abandoned buildings, a hop from the projects in Newark's South Bronx.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bosnians Reported to Repel Serb Attack
nytimes_articles.abstract: Bosnian Government troops repulsed new attacks by Serbian nationalist forces today on the "safe area" of Gorazde, the last Muslim enclave in eastern Bosnia that the Serbs have not overrun or neutralized, amateur radio operators reported.   After reports of Serbian artillery attacks on Sunday and infantry assaults that brought Serbian forces to within a few miles of the town of Gorazde, Bosnian officials demanded in Geneva today that the United Nations immediately deploy United Nations military forces in the Gorazde pocket, where some 60,000 people, including tens of thousands of refugees, are trapped.

nytimes_articles.headline: AZERBAIJAN CHIEF FIGHTS REBELLION
nytimes_articles.abstract: Trying to save his Government from a growing insurrection, President Abulfez Elchibey of Azerbaijan said today that military force would be used against the rebels, even if it means plunging the former Soviet republic into civil war.    "The legitimately elected Government of Azerbaijan has the right to defend the country from falling into the control of criminals and bandits," Mr. Elchibey told foreign ambassadors and journalists in Baku, the capital. "If the rebels do not stop their actions, we will be obliged to respond with force."

nytimes_articles.headline: Degrees Conferred At Merchant Marine
nytimes_articles.abstract: United States Secretary of Transportation Federico F. Pena delivered the keynote address yesterday to 203 graduates at the United States Merchant Marine Academy's 57th commencement exercises.   "The Clinton Administration is committed to expanding trade opportunities all over the world, including our North American Trade Agreement with Canada and Mexico and similar accords with other nations in the future," Secretary Pena said.  "But we are also committed to insuring a level playing field -- the same access for American goods and services in foreign markets that our partners enjoy in American markets."

nytimes_articles.headline: Reviews/Dance; 3 Russian Composers Plus One Balanchine
nytimes_articles.abstract: The New York City Ballet's Balanchine Celebration on Friday night at the New York State Theater celebrated not only the choreography of George Balanchine, but also the music of three Russian composers: Tchaikovsky, Stravinsky and Glazunov.    To describe "Tchaikovsky Suite No. 3" as a choreographic matching of musical forms is accurate enough. But Balanchine did more than mirror music. He created an implicitly dramatic ballet that begins in unrest and ends in emotional balance and well-being.

nytimes_articles.headline: Rejected as a Clerk, Chosen as a Justice - Ruth Bader Ginsburg
nytimes_articles.abstract: WASHINGTON -- In 1960, a dean at the Harvard Law School, Albert Sachs, proposed one of his star students to Justice Felix Frankfurter of the Supreme Court as a law clerk. Justice Frankfurter told Professor Sachs that while the candidate was impressive, he just wasn't ready to hire a woman and so couldn't offer a job to Ruth Bader Ginsburg.

nytimes_articles.headline: INSIDE
nytimes_articles.abstract: Haitians Leave Guantanamo   After 20 months of confinement, a group of H.I.V.-infected Haitians was flown to the United States. Page A20. Rules on Vitamins Sought    The Food and Drug Administration will renew its efforts to regulate dietary supplements. Page A25. Dispute Over Baby Formula    The American Academy of Pediatrics is accused of helping to fix baby-formula prices. Page D1. Doctors Plan Opposition    Leaders of the American Medical Association plan to oppose key parts of the Clinton health plan. Page A20.

nytimes_articles.headline: Legislators Deadlocked On Rent Laws
nytimes_articles.abstract: In what has become a ritual of the legislative session, the laws that limit rent increases on nearly 900,000 apartments in New York City and surrounding counties expire at the end of the day Tuesday, and state legislators remained deadlocked today on whether to extend them.   Every two years the state's rent-control and rent-stabilization laws expire, setting off a fight in the Legislature between supporters of tenants and landlords, who make competing calls to change the system. In past years, legislators have waited until the 11th hour to resolve the issue, and then compromised by extending the existing rent rules another two years.

nytimes_articles.headline: Abortion-Protest Case
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Supreme Court agreed to decide whether abortion clinics can use a Federal racketeering law that provides for triple damages to sue anti-abortion groups that organize demonstrations and blockades intended to shut down the clinics.    Article, page A22.

nytimes_articles.headline: Williams Grand Slam Wins It for Kamieniecki
nytimes_articles.abstract: All it took was one misplay and one beautiful swing and this game was all over. Certainly, Scott Kamieniecki helped -- he came back from a brief visit to the minor leagues and pitched eight shutout innings for the Yankees, giving up three hits.   But as much as anything, it was a combination of Mo Vaughn and Bernie Williams that beat the Red Sox at Yankee Stadium last night. Vaughn, the Boston first baseman, made a crucial error that helped load the bases in the fifth inning. And Williams took advantage, sending an inside fastball from Danny Darwin into the right-field seats for his first career grand slam and a 4-0 New York victory.

nytimes_articles.headline: Federal Trade Omission
nytimes_articles.abstract: "Get heart smart," implores a current magazine advertisement for a popular brand of margarine. The illustration is a heart-shaped pat of margarine melting over string beans, reinforcing the implied claim that this is a sound choice to prevent heart disease.    This appeal to health-conscious consumers may be smart marketing strategy for the manufacturer. But it's dumb national health policy to permit a misleading health claim in advertising that the Food and Drug Administration no longer permits on food package labels. With six grams of fat per tablespoon, even this "extra light" spread is a fatty food that can actually help promote heart disease.

nytimes_articles.headline: Tune In to Democracy
nytimes_articles.abstract: Over the next two days, House appropriations and Senate foreign relations subcommittees will begin deciding whether to create Radio Free Asia -- to do for such tyrannies as China, North Korea, Vietnam, Laos and Burma what Radio Liberty and Radio Free Europe did for Communist Europe.    The Administration is expected to weigh in with a recommendation. If President Clinton, who chose to extend China's most-favored-nation status without any human rights conditions, wants to retain credibility as an advocate of global democracy, he'll want to make sure a robust plan for Radio Free Asia goes forward. In de-fending his decision, he said we have an interest in China's modernization. But this is true only if China's political development goes hand-in-hand with its economic development. A China that grows rich and powerful without becoming democratic will be more of a menace than a blessing.

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: The invitation carried the first hint that the party tonight for HARVEY LICHTENSTEIN, president and executive director of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, would be no staid affair. On its cover, encapsulating the history of mankind, were these designations: "Stone Age," "Machine Age," "Atomic Age" and "The Harvey Years."    Some 380 friends and colleagues will get together at the academy to celebrate "the Harvey years" -- the era that began 25 years ago when he took over and transformed the academy from a declining cultural center to a highly successful showcase for experimental performances of all sorts.

nytimes_articles.headline: Senate Mailings Are Criticized By Democrats
nytimes_articles.abstract: Using a freedom of information request for postal records, a group of Democratic Senators demonstrated today that most taxpayer-financed legislative mail is sent out shortly before elections.   "This is a graphic demonstration that what we have in New York State is public campaign financing without the public's permission," said Senator Richard A. Dollinger, a Democrat from the Rochester area.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Television; Two Views of Dying of AIDS, From the Flippant to the Poignant
nytimes_articles.abstract: "Silverlake Life: The View From Here" and "The Broadcast Tapes of Dr. Peter" are video diaries of men dying of AIDS. Both, of course, are inherently sad, but for all the similarities of content, their impact is strikingly different. "Silverlake Life" opens the new "P.O.V." ("Point of View") documentary season tonight on PBS, and "The Broadcast Tapes" will be shown on July 1 on HBO.   Peter Jepson-Young, a Vancouver, British Columbia, doctor in his 30's whose weekly accounts of the workings of the disease were shown on Canadian television from 1990 through 1992, used the medium as a way of helping others understand what he was going through and somehow help himself bear with it. Perhaps he was sustained by his medical training. By contrast, Tom Joslin, a California film maker, and his lover, Mark Massi, seem to be coming on to the camera, giving a show that almost trivializes their suffering.

nytimes_articles.headline: A 1993 MacArthur Award Adds New Joy to a Singer's Hallelujahs
nytimes_articles.abstract: Marion Williams was in church last Friday when she was called to the telephone: A philanthropy in Chicago wanted to tell her she had won $374,000.   No strings. No conditions. She would receive the money over the next five years to spend as she wished.

nytimes_articles.headline: Transcript of President's Announcement and Judge Ginsburg's Remarks
nytimes_articles.abstract: Following is a transcript of remarks today by President Clinton and Judge Ruth Bader Ginsburg, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a transcription company: BY PRESIDENT CLINTON    Please be seated. I wish you all a good afternoon, and I thank the members of the Congress and other interested Americans who are here. In just a few days when the Supreme Court concludes its term, Justice Byron White will begin a new chapter in his long and productive life. He has served the Court as he has lived, with distinction, intelligence, and honor. And he retires from public service with the deep gratitude of all the American people.

nytimes_articles.headline: 1943:Filling the Forces : IN OUR PAGES: 100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: WASHINGTON - [From our New York edition:] The drafting of fathers may be delayed a few months, it was indicated today [June 14] as Selective Service took steps to speed up the induction of childless men who deferred because of their occupations. The Selec

nytimes_articles.headline: Bulls' Only Concern: Referees
nytimes_articles.abstract: Do things suddenly look shaky for the Bulls as they approach Game 4 of their championship playoff series with the Phoenix Suns? Does this Chicago team, which has won two straight National Basketball Association titles, have anything to worry about, realistically?   "We're still in the driver's seat," Chicago forward Scottie Pippen said this morning, with the series still in the Bulls' favor at two games to one. "We're just a little tired."

nytimes_articles.headline: Hellooo, Down There: Is That You, Mets?
nytimes_articles.abstract: Major league club owners are scheduled Thursday to adopt a plan to expand the post-season playoffs from two teams in each league to four beginning next year. The owners are prepared to shatter baseball tradition by allowing nonchampionship teams into their post-season party because they believe the additional invitations will create late-season fan interest.   If it's interest-building gimmicks they want, why wait? This season's developments have created a ready-made gimmick for another type of playoff. This one would involve the four worst teams in each league, or at least the National League, because that's where the most intriguing developments have occurred.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sports of The Times; Sports Rule: Always Root For Visitors
nytimes_articles.abstract: WHAT a great game in Chicago on Sunday. The world champions taking on the upstarts. Huge, knowledgeable, boisterous crowd. Mood swings in the high-scoring game. The outcome in doubt until the final seconds.   There was also a basketball game.

nytimes_articles.headline: Johnson's 62 Minutes Make Him Man of Hour
nytimes_articles.abstract: Opponents, and even teammates, have noticed a harder edge to Kevin Johnson this season. Johnson admits to the change in attitude. And it is not a coincidence.   The Phoenix Suns' talented point guard has stopped worrying about the opinions of outsiders and has concentrated solely on winning. That attitude has rubbed some people the wrong way, but Johnson offers no apologies. The Suns are in the finals, and thanks largely to Johnson's record-setting 62-minute performance in Game 3, the Suns still have a realistic chance at their first title in franchise history.

nytimes_articles.headline: THE SUPREME COURT: Woman in the News; Rejected as a Clerk, Chosen as a Justice: Ruth Joan Bader Ginsburg
nytimes_articles.abstract: In 1960, a dean at the Harvard Law School, Albert Sachs, proposed one of his star students to Justice Felix Frankfurter of the Supreme Court as a law clerk. Justice Frankfurter told Professor Sachs that while the candidate was impressive, he just wasn't ready to hire a woman and so couldn't offer a job to Ruth Bader Ginsburg.   Judge Ginsburg, who now sits on the Federal appeals court and was chosen today by President Clinton for the Supreme Court, recently told that story to her own law clerks to explain how she became interested in the role of women in the eyes of the law. Force Before the Court    In the years between that rebuff by Justice Frankfurter and her appointment to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit in 1980, Ruth Ginsburg was a major force on the other side of the Supreme Court's high bench.

nytimes_articles.headline: Body Found Floating Off Queens Coastline
nytimes_articles.abstract: The body of a man was found yesterday floating off the Queens shoreline at Breezy Point, the police said.   There was no identification on the body, but the police said the man was Asian. Sgt. Virgil Hickmon of the 101st Precinct Detective Squad said there was "a possibility" that the man may have been from the ill-fated ship Golden Venture, which was smuggling Chinese immigrants when it went aground last week off the Rockaway Peninsula.

nytimes_articles.headline: NEWS SUMMARY
nytimes_articles.abstract: International A3-18  U.S. DRAWS LINE ON GLOBAL RIGHTS  At a conference in Vienna, the United States warned that it would oppose attempts to use religious and cultural traditions to erode the concept of universal human rights.  A1  DESTINY IS IN SIHANOUK'S HANDS  Cambodia's new Parliament met for the first time and gave Prince Norodom Sihanouk all of the powers necessary "to save our nation." A3

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. Open Usually Belongs to Americans
nytimes_articles.abstract: While the other major championships in golf have a distinctly international list of winners, the United States Open has traditionally been distinctly American.   The last foreign-born winner of the championship was David Graham of Australia, who won at Merion in 1981. Before that, it was Tony Jacklin of England in 1970, and South African Gary Player in 1965. Before that, you have to go back to 1927 and Scottish-born Tommy Armour.

nytimes_articles.headline: 1893:Shakespeare's Jug : IN OUR PAGES: 100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: LONDON - Relics of the greatest of dramatists were on sale at Christie's yesterday [June 14]. One was Shakespeare's jug of cream-colored earthenware. It was divided longitudinally into eight compartments, each horizontally subdivided, and within, principa

nytimes_articles.headline: Havana Journal; 43,412 Stricken Cubans, and Not a Single Answer
nytimes_articles.abstract: On the 15th floor of the Hermanos Almeijeiras Hospital, the towering downtown complex that is the pride of Cuba's medical establishment, new patients arrive each day with a mysterious ailment that has left many people sightless and set off a global scramble to determine its cause.    Some patients with the disease, which has been variously described as optic neuropathy and peripheral neuropathy, writhe and grimace as muscles in their legs and arms flicker in and out of spasm. Others lie listlessly, their vision blurred and their other senses confused. Since the disorder of the nervous system first surfaced at the end of 1991, the illness has been diagnosed in 43,412 people, the Cuban authorities say.

nytimes_articles.headline: Intra-Party Fights Complicate Florio-Whitman Race
nytimes_articles.abstract: Jim Florio already has his hands full battling the Republicans in his gubernatorial campaign, and Christine Todd Whitman will be under constant fire from the Democrats. That's to be expected.   But just to make things interesting, both candidates also face nagging problems in their own parties that at best are unwelcome distractions, and at worst could undermine efforts to get the vote out in November.

nytimes_articles.headline: Valuable Diploma or Meaningless Piece of Paper?
nytimes_articles.abstract: A year ago, Charisse Dangerfield, a cherub-faced 16-year-old from the Bronx, was just another student bored with the rigors of getting a good education. On more days than she can count, she shortened her misery by skipping math and any other classes she found especially dull.   "I was doing badly," she said, her words accented by the rhythmic smacks of her chewing gum. "I just wasn't doing my work."

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: The pupils in the fourth grade at the Chapin School figured out recently that MILDRED J. BERENDSEN, had eaten 11,380 birthday cupcakes, signed 60,400 report cards and handed out 1,169 diplomas during her tenure as headmistress.   So commencement tomorrow will be a bittersweet occasion: Mrs. Berendsen, 65, is retiring after 44 years at the private girls' school on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: A front-page article yesterday about the selection of Kim Campbell to be Prime Minister of Canada referred incorrectly in some editions to June Rowland, one of several other women who have assumed high office in Canada. She is the Mayor of Toronto.

nytimes_articles.headline: Conner Presents Cup Sponsor
nytimes_articles.abstract: Just as his campaign to win the Whitbread Round the World Race is heating up, DENNIS CONNER is digging his heels deeper into his 1995 America's Cup yachting effort.    At a news conference yesterday at the "21" Club in Manhattan, Conner announced that Citizen Watch Company has become his first gold-level sponsor, a designation that translates into $3 million, a tenth of Conner's 1995 goal.

nytimes_articles.headline: Books of The Times; Decline of America's Landscape and the Blame
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Geography of Nowhere  The Rise and Decline of America's Man-Made Landscape  By James Howard Kunstler  303 pages. Simon & Schuster. $23.   "Eighty percent of everything ever built in America has been built in the last 50 years," writes the novelist and reporter James Howard Kunstler in his stimulating new book, "and most of it is depressing, brutal, ugly, unhealthy and spiritually degrading: the jive-plastic commuter tract home wastelands, the Potemkin village shopping plazas with their vast parking lagoons, the Lego-block hotel complexes, the 'gourmet mansardic' junk-food joints, the Orwellian office 'parks' featuring buildings sheathed in the same reflective glass as the sunglasses worn by chain-gang guards, the particle-board garden apartments rising up in every meadow and cornfield, the freeway loops around every big and little city with their clusters of discount merchandise marts, the whole destructive, wasteful, toxic, agoraphobia-inducing spectacle that politicians proudly call 'growth.' "

nytimes_articles.headline: In the Race for Public Advocate, 6 Is a Crowd
nytimes_articles.abstract: With three months before the Democratic mayoral primary, the race for public advocate is shaping up as perhaps the most intriguing but most convoluted election in New York City.   There are six major Democratic candidates representing overlapping racial and ethnic categories, and even, on the part of one, a fusion with the Republican Party. Meanwhile, Mayor David N. Dinkins is apparently reluctant to take sides because the contest includes several allies, including the son of one of his closest confidants. What's more, most voters don't seem to know what the race is all about.

nytimes_articles.headline: Jupiter's Watery Moon
nytimes_articles.abstract: NASA researchers have found the first strong evidence of water on the surface of Jupiter's moon Io.   Ice from water is mixed with more abundant sulfur dioxide ice on the orange-and-yellow moon.

nytimes_articles.headline: Lack of Sex Information Drives Up Teen-Age Pregnancy Rate
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Your June 3 report of a 17-year-old Long Island girl who gave birth to a baby and then placed him in a trash can missed an important point: While your sources talked at length about the young woman's inability to pay for prenatal care, very little attention was paid to her apparent inability to talk to her parents about her plight.

nytimes_articles.headline: Prison Term For Doctor Convicted In Abortions
nytimes_articles.abstract: Calling the case one "that shocks us all," a judge yesterday sentenced the East Village doctor who severed the arm of a fetus in attempting an illegal abortion to 9 and two-thirds to 29 years in prison.   The lawyer for Dr. Abu Hayat called the penalty a "a death sentence" for the 63-year-old doctor. A lawyer for one of the victims, as well as an official of the District Attorney's Office, said they supported the sentence but were surprised by its severity.

nytimes_articles.headline: To Defend the Country : LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Regarding "Do They Really Want to Be Part of This?" (Meanwhile, June 8)by Colman McCarthy: .I agree with Colman McCarthy's plea that gays shouldn't be in the military and women shouldn't be in combat - but not for quite the same reason (that

nytimes_articles.headline: Soccer and Television Make a Bad Sports Mix
nytimes_articles.abstract: At 1:20 P.M. Sunday, I slept. I didn't mean to. I just did. And I dozed several more times during ABC's telecast of the United States-Germany World Cup warmup. I really want to like soccer.   Well, I want not to loathe soccer -- and to understand the worldwide hype for it, the passion that makes enraged fans attack referees, the reason why millions of American children play soccer, and why intelligent people think next year's World Cup here will be a sports-business landmark.

nytimes_articles.headline: Can U.N. Survive Continued Failure in Bosnia?
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   If the United Nations continues its ineffective policy in Bosnia, it could itself become the main casualty of the fighting. Failure to bring a cessation of aggression and an end to the worst bloodshed in Europe since World War II will lead to a major global loss of faith in the world organization.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bloody Sunday in Somalia
nytimes_articles.abstract: A week after 23 United Nations peacekeepers were killed by Somali gunmen, an obviously rattled group of Pakistani peacekeepers opened fire on Somali civilians. It was precisely the wrong target; women, children and civilian demonstrators are not the enemies in Mogadishu. The Pakistanis' grievous error handed a propaganda windfall to the Mogadishu warlord Mohammed Farah Aidid.    It would compound the tragedy if General Aidid, the culprit responsible for so much suffering in Somalia, is able to portray himself as a victim. President Clinton was justified in sending more warplanes to Somalia in support of the 20-nation peacemaking effort. But yesterday's accidental strike at a civilian target by a Cobra gunship shows the need for greater care in targeting.

nytimes_articles.headline: Fairness Debated in Quick Transplant
nytimes_articles.abstract: Since Gov. Robert P. Casey of Pennsylvania received a new heart and liver in a 15-hour operation on Monday, the question being asked by doctors, experts in medical ethics, radio talk show hosts and their call-in listeners is: How did the Governor jump to the head of the organ-transplant line?   It took less than a day to find a suitable donor for Governor Casey, in contrast to average patients who wait 67 days for a new liver and 198 days for a new heart.

nytimes_articles.headline: General to Be Disciplined For Disparaging President
nytimes_articles.abstract: An Air Force inquiry has concluded that a two-star general made disparaging remarks about President Clinton, and the general now faces disciplinary action that will effectively end his career, senior Air Force officials said today.   The Air Force inquiry found that the officer, Maj. Gen. Harold N. Campbell, called Mr. Clinton a "dope-smoking," "skirt-chasing," "draft-dodging" Commander in Chief, in a speech last month in the Netherlands.

nytimes_articles.headline: Germany's Demon Moviemaker
nytimes_articles.abstract: Rainer Werner Fassbinder, the demon filmmaker of the New German Cinema, used and abused powerful substances - love, sex, power, drugs - with abandon. It was drugs that did him in: he died June 10, 1982, at 37. Now a tribute to this remarkable director, a

nytimes_articles.headline: Asylum Reform Has to Respect Human Rights
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "The Golden Venture, Plus 100,000" (editorial, June 9), recommending "stricter standards of proof" and expedited asylum hearings for the nearly 300 Chinese who survived the voyage of the freighter Golden Venture misses an important point. While the United States asylum system is indeed inundated with a backlog of more than 250,000 cases, last year only 3,440 Chinese asylum claims were received by the Immigration and Naturalization Service. Indeed, 85 percent of those Chinese cases were approved by the agency on the ground that the individuals were refugees with a well-founded fear of persecution.

nytimes_articles.headline: Barkley Says His Injury Will Not Keep Him Out
nytimes_articles.abstract: Charles Barkley, the Suns' All-Star forward, said today that his injured right elbow was still swollen and sore, but that he would be in the lineup Wednesday night when Phoenix meets the Chicago Bulls in Game 4 of the National Basketball Association finals.   "Some more fluids built up, and we might have to drain it before the game tomorrow," said Barkley, who injured the elbow in Game 2 last Friday night in Phoenix. "But we'll just have to go out and do the best we can. It's sore and it's tender."

nytimes_articles.headline: Castro, a Reluctant Landlord, Won't Cash the Rent Check
nytimes_articles.abstract:
Looking for a few good bases to close? Start with our naval base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba. 

Notorious as the processing station for fleeing Haitians (and as a veritable prison for Haitians carrying H.I.V. until their release this week), the outpost serves no purpose that couldn't be served as effectively by Roosevelt Roads Naval Base in Puerto Rico.

nytimes_articles.headline: Ruled Dead by Medical Workers, A Brooklyn Woman, 40, Is Alive
nytimes_articles.abstract: A 40-year-old Brooklyn woman, pronounced dead by emergency medical technicians, lay on the floor of her apartment for nearly three hours on Monday night until an investigator from the city Medical Examiner's office heard a gurgling sound and realized that she was alive.   The woman, Nancy Vitale, was unconscious and in critical condition yesterday at Coney Island Hospital. Her mother said Ms. Vitale had recently been upset because she had been let go from her job as a teacher at a Catholic elementary school.

nytimes_articles.headline: Three Sides in Bosnia Sign One More Cease-Fire
nytimes_articles.abstract: On another day marred by clashes between Bosnian Army forces and Serbian and Croatian militias across this war-savaged land, the commanders of the three military forces here agreed today to a yet another cease-fire.   After a four-hour meeting at the Sarajevo airport, Rasim Delic, the Bosnian commander, Gen. Ratko Mladic of the Bosnian Serbs and Milivoj Petkovic, the Croatian commander, put their signatures to a document pledging unconditionally "to freeze all military activities" by noon Friday local time. But dozens of earlier countrywide cease-fire accords have never yielded more than a few days of peace. Most have been stillborn.

nytimes_articles.headline: Metro-North Looking at Going to Beach
nytimes_articles.abstract: The next time you are on the way to the beach, rather than at the beach, because of traffic on the highways and bridges, think about boarding an air-conditioned Metro-North train in Yonkers or Tarrytown, whisking through Penn Station and then out to Jones Beach, the Fire Island ferries or even Montauk.   Sound attractive?

nytimes_articles.headline: BOOKS : PAPER DREAMS
nytimes_articles.abstract: PAPER DREAMS

nytimes_articles.headline: F.D.A. SEEKS RULES ON DRUGS' TESTERS
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Food and Drug Administration is planning to require that pharmaceutical companies disclose any important financial connections they have to doctors testing drugs and some medical devices as part of the new drug application process.   The Commissioner of Food and Drugs, Dr. David A. Kessler, said the new policy, expected to be sent out for public comment later this year, was intended to prevent bias in drug testing that might result if doctors stood to gain financially from positive results of experiments.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: An article on Saturday about a housing desegregation case in Yonkers misstated the number of families that have received approval as tenants from cooperative building boards. Only one of the four qualified families needs the approval of a cooperative board, and that family has not yet received such approval.

nytimes_articles.headline: John Connally of Texas, a Power In 2 Political Parties, Dies at 76
nytimes_articles.abstract: John B. Connally, the former Governor of Texas who served in two Presidential Administrations and who was wounded when President John F. Kennedy was assassinated, died yesterday at Methodist Hospital in Houston. He was 76.    The cause was complications of pulmonary fibrosis, said a hospital spokeswoman, Blythe Schaffer. Mr. Connally had been admitted to the hospital May 17 with breathing problems.

nytimes_articles.headline: INSIDE
nytimes_articles.abstract: Verdict in Principal's Death   Three teen-agers were convicted of killing a popular elementary school principal in Brooklyn. Page B1. Soda Tampering Mystery    Reports of syringes in cans of Pepsi spread to 11 states, and the Food and Drug Administration is investigating the 16 incidents. Page A16. Sex and the Law in Ireland    Ireland has begun to move steadily toward a liberalization of laws involving families and sex. Page A10.

nytimes_articles.headline: LAWMAKERS FIGHT NEW ATOMIC TESTS
nytimes_articles.abstract: Democratic lawmakers have mounted a strong effort to dissuade the Clinton Administration from a plan to resume tests of nuclear weapons after a Congressional moratorium expires July 1.   The plan calls for the United States and Britain to conduct nine underground explosions in Nevada before 1996, when the Administration wants a complete test ban to go into effect.

nytimes_articles.headline: Man Kills Boy and Injures 2 With Machete
nytimes_articles.abstract: A man whose parents took him in last year after he had spent months living on the streets took a machete this morning and hacked to death his 17-month-old grand-nephew and injured his 3-year-old grand-niece and his father, the Nassau County Police said.   The man, Mark Mitchell, 36, was arrested about 9:20 A.M. as he sat calmly on the steps of his parents' home, across from his bleeding father, Thomas, 67, said Lieut. Frank Guidice.

nytimes_articles.headline: No Headline
nytimes_articles.abstract: "We should do what people do in Mudpuddle, Utah. Make quilts, bake cakes -- it seems like an awfully cheap price for a hospital." -- JACQUELINE LOFARO of Cold Spring, N.Y., on efforts to keep the local hospital open.  [ B5:3. ]

nytimes_articles.headline: Condensing a Riot's Cacophony Into the Voice of One Woman
nytimes_articles.abstract: One day after her triumphal opening night in Los Angeles, complete with a standing ovation and more flowers than she could carry, Anna Deavere Smith sat slumped in a quiet West Hollywood restaurant still puzzled, even dazed, by the fear and confusion that grips the city after last year's riots.   "I have very haunting dreams," said the 42-year-old performer, writer and Stanford University professor. "What's around is very grave. But I believe things can change. And even though I've spent time talking to people in a tragic moment, dramatically and linguistically it couldn't be more fascinating."

nytimes_articles.headline: Women at the Top
nytimes_articles.abstract: Two more countries elected women as their Prime Ministers last weekend, but that's hardly news anymore. The list of women who head or have headed their governments grows by the year, and notably in countries where feminist movements are weak or nonexistent.   Following in the giant footsteps of Israel's Golda Meir, Britain's Margaret Thatcher, India's Indira Gandhi, Pakistan's Benazir Bhutto, Sri Lanka's Sirimavo Bandaranaike and still others, the current roster includes:

nytimes_articles.headline: Handicaps Are No Bar, A Medical School Says
nytimes_articles.abstract: After fighting for more than two years to get into medical school, a 23-year-old quadriplegic has been accepted by Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx.   When the wheelchair-bound student, James B. Post 4th, graduated last year from King's College in Wilkes-Barre, Pa., his grade-point average was 3.922 and his medical-school admission test scores were above average. But his application was rejected by 10 medical schools; he said they told him they could not accommodate a quadriplegic student.

nytimes_articles.headline: Wickman's Night Begins in Folly and Ends in Glee
nytimes_articles.abstract: He went into the Yankee clubhouse at the close of the fourth inning, let the door slam behind him with a thump of disgust.   Bob Wickman did not want to watch the rest of this ball game, did not want to stare up at the Yankee Stadium scoreboard at those awful five runs he had given the Red Sox. His team had none and Boston had five, and Wickman figured it was near to hopeless. He figured he was due -- deservedly due -- his first loss of the year.

nytimes_articles.headline: Senators Seek to Ease Filibuster's Grip on Campaign Finance Bill
nytimes_articles.abstract: Senate Democrats struggled today to keep campaign finance legislation alive by dealing with moderate Republicans who want to eliminate almost all public financing from the bill but keep its voluntary spending limits.   If all the elements of the emerging plan fall into place -- and significant opposition to several of its parts seems certain -- the negotiators hope to win a vote on Wednesday to end a filibuster against the bill. Supporters of the bill lost just such a vote earlier today, falling 8 votes short of the 60 required to cut off debate.

nytimes_articles.headline: Backed by Kemp, Giuliani Says He Expects to Ride Winning Tide
nytimes_articles.abstract: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal candidate for mayor, received the endorsement of Jack Kemp yesterday and promised to be the next Republican to ride to victory on a tide of fiscal conservatism tempered by social concern.
